The '''All India Democratic Women's Association''' (AIDWA) (in [[Hindi]]: अखिल भारतीय जनवादी महिला समिति) is the women's wing of the [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]].<ref name="hinduonnet.com">[http://www.hinduonnet.com/thehindu/mag/2003/01/05/stories/2003010500020400.htm The Hindu, 5 January 2003]</ref>

==History and Scope==
[[Pappa Umanath]] founded the Democratic Women's Association in Tamil Nadu in 1973, working for women's rights and for their education, employment and status, along with issues like casteism,<ref name="hinduonnet.com"/> communalism, child rights and disaster aid.<ref name=tsunami/> Several other affiliated State-based organisations developed, and the unified All India Democratic Women's Association (AIDWA) was established in 1981.<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2010/12/18/stories/2010121852810400.htm CPI (M) leader Pappa Umanath passes away, 18 December 2010]</ref><ref>[http://humanrights.progressiveislam.org/index.php/All_India_Democratic_Women's_Association AIDWA profile]</ref>

AIDWA has an annual membership fee of one rupee, which allows it policy-independence from donor agencies and government.<ref name=tsunami>[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-30283788_ITM Women and Aid distribution AIDWA] Meridians: feminism, race, transnationalism, June 2006</ref> In 2007, it had over 10 million members, spread across 23 states.<ref>[http://www.cpim.org/pd/2007/1104/11042007_aidwa.htm 8TH All India Conference Of AIDWA, November 2007, Calcutta]</ref>

===2002 campaign against Hindustan Lever advertising===
Subtle cultural norms can be easily transgressed. In 2002, widespread protests forced Hindustan Lever Ltd. (the Indian subsidiary of London-based Unilever) to cancel  a television ad campaign for its fairness cream because of its portrayal of women. The campaign was built around the theme of a father lamenting "If only I had a son" while showing his problem: a dark-skinned, unattractive daughter. Fast-forward. She uses the [[Fair & Lovely (cosmetics)|Fair & Lovely]] cream and has become a gorgeous light-skinned beauty. Clad in a stylish miniskirt, she is a successful airline flight attendant and takes her proud father to dine at a five-star hotel. AIDWA lodged a complaint with the National Human Rights Commission in New Delhi. It argued endorsing the traditional preference for sons strengthens gender discrimination, which is a major problem in India. Furthermore, said AIDWA, the ad perpetuated a culture of discrimination in a society where "fair skin" is synonymous with "beautiful."  The government's Ministry of Information and Broadcast sided with AIDWA and directed stations not to air the ads because they violated the Cable and Television Networks Act of 1995 which states that no advertisement shall be permitted which "derides any race, caste, color, creed and nationality" and furthermore states that, "Women must not be portrayed in a manner that emphasizes passive, submissive qualities and encourages them to play a subordinate secondary role in the family and society."  The minister told Parliament that if broadcasters do not regulate ad content the government will be forced to do so. The Mumbai-based Advertising Standards Council of India (ASCI), a body of advertisers and media agencies, insisted that it should do the regulating not the government. ASCI had already told Hindustan Lever that its ad campaign was offensive and it was ended.<ref>Arundhati Parmar, "Objections to Indian ad not taken lightly" ''Marketing News'' (9 June 2003) 37#12 pp 4-9</ref>

==National Conference of AIDWA==
The first National Conference of AIDWA was held at [[Chennai]] in 1981, with delegates from 12 states representing 590,000 members. The eighth National Conference was held at [[Kolkata]] in 2007, with 951 delegates from 23 states, representing a membership of around 18,600,000. Former West Bengal Chief Minister [[Jyoti Basu]] addressed the inaugural session.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flonnet.com/fl2423/stories/20071207509110200.htm|title=Call for Action|last=Chattopadhyayt|first=Suhrid Sankar|date=4 December 2007|work=Frontline|accessdate=13 June 2014}}</ref>

===10th National Conference===
AIDWA's 10th National Conference was held  in [[Bodh Gaya]], [[Bihar]], from 22 to 25 November 2013. It started with flag hoisting by AIDWA's national president [[Shyamali Gupta]] and homage to martyrs who sacrificed their lives for [[women's emancipation]] and [[social justice]]. The inaugural session featured a special session titled "Women against Violence: Fighting for Justice, Resisting Violence, Claiming Rights", wherein women from across the country who have been fighting the battle against violence, discrimination and social injustice in various forms which includes domestic and political violence, [[sexual assault]], fight for [[land rights]], fight against [[caste]] and communal discrimination and against terrorism spoke. The women who spoke included representative of the [[Vachathi]] tribal mass rape survivor from [[Tamil Nadu]], Parandhayi, who stood up against her sexual assault by forest and police officials for 19 long years and finally succeeded in getting justice.<ref>{{cite web|title=AIDWA’s National Conference|url=http://ganashakti.com/english/news/top_story/3562|publisher=India News Network (INN)|accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref>

==Regional Affiliations==
Its regional affiliates include [[Paschimbangla Ganatantrik Mahila Samiti]] ([[West Bengal]]), [[Ganatantrik Nari Samiti]] ([[Tripura]]), and [[Janwadi Mahila Sanghatan]] ([[Maharashtra]]).

'''Alpha Kappa Alpha''' ('''ΑΚΑ''') was the first [[Greek alphabet|Greek-lettered]] [[Fraternities and sororities in North America|sorority]] established and incorporated by [[African-American]] college women. Membership is for college educated women.<ref>[http://www.aka1908.com/membership/honorary-members.html] {{wayback|url=http://www.aka1908.com/membership/honorary-members.html |date=20121019005421 }}</ref> The sorority was founded on January 15, 1908, at [[Howard University]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], by a group of sixteen students, led by [[Ethel Hedgeman Lyle]]. Forming a sorority broke barriers for African-American women in areas where little power or authority existed due to a lack of opportunities for minorities and women in the early 20th century.<ref>Tamara L. Brown, Gregory Parks, Clarenda M. Phillips, ''African American Fraternities and Sororities: The Legacy and the Vision''. Lexington: University Press of Kentucky, 2005. p. 342</ref> Alpha Kappa Alpha was [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] on January 29, 1913.

Consisting of college-educated women of many diverse backgrounds from around the world, including [[Black race|African]], [[Caucasian race|Caucasian]], [[Asian people|Asian]], [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]], [[Hispanic]] and [[India]]n descent, the sorority serves through a membership of more than 283,000 women in 992 chapters in the United States and several other countries.<ref name=AKAmember/> Women may join through undergraduate chapters at a college or university or they may also join through a graduate chapter after acquiring  an undergraduate or advanced college degree.<ref name=AKAint>{{cite web |year=2006 |url=http://www.akainternational.org/main/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26&Itemid=34    |title=Historical Overview|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated. – International Region|accessdate=2007-05-09}}</ref>

After the organization's establishment, Alpha Kappa Alpha has helped to improve social and economic conditions through community service programs. Members have improved education through independent initiatives, contributed to community-building by creating programs and associations, such as the Mississippi Health Clinic, and influenced federal legislation by [[U.S. Congress|Congressional]] lobbying through the National Non-Partisan Lobby on Civil and Democratic Rights. The sorority works with communities through service initiatives and progressive programs relating to education, family, health, and business.

Alpha Kappa Alpha is part of the [[National Pan-Hellenic Council]] (NPHC). The current International President is Dorothy Buckhanan Wilson, and the sorority's document and pictorial archives are located at [[Moorland-Spingarn Research Center]].

==History==
[[File:MainandMiner Hall.GIF|thumb|Main Hall and Miner Hall in 1868. Miner Hall is located to the left.<ref name=minerhall>{{cite web |title=Gallery – Part II: The Progressive Era, 1890–1910|date=August 1999|url=http://www.huarchivesnet.howard.edu/9908huarnet/power/progress/progress/sld010.htm|publisher=Moreland-Spingarn Research Center at Howard University|accessdate=2007-10-12}}</ref> Miner Hall was the site of Alpha Kappa Alpha's founding on January 15, 1908.<ref name=lambdaeta-2>{{cite web |date=2005-04-21 |url=http://www.msstate.edu/org/aka/newfacts.html |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20050525035516/http://www.msstate.edu/org/aka/newfacts.html |archivedate=2005-05-25 |title=Alpha Kappa Alpha Important Facts |publisher=Lambda Eta Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-30}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref> The building was demolished in 1961.<ref name=demolish>{{cite web |date=May 2003|author=Matthew Gilmore |url=http://www.h-net.org/~dclist/goode2.htm |title=Capitol Losses, Second Edition|publisher=H-Net, Humanities & Social Sciences OnLine|accessdate=2007-10-13}}</ref>]]

===Beginnings: 1907–1912===
In spring 1907, Ethel Hedgeman led efforts to create a sisterhood at Howard University. Howard faculty member Ethal Robinson encouraged Hedgeman by relating her own observances of sorority life at the Women's College at [[Brown University]], even though she was not a member of any sorority while a student at Brown.<ref name="Ross-166">Ross, Jr., ''The Divine Nine'', p. 166.</ref><ref name="delta">{{cite book
  |last=Giddings
  |first=Paula
  |title=In Search of Sisterhood: Delta Sigma Theta and the Challenge of the Black Sorority Movement
  |publisher=[[HarperCollins]] Publishers
  |year=1988
  |location=New York, New York
  |isbn=0-688-13509-9
  |page=44}}</ref> Hedgeman was also inspired by her mentors at Howard. To implement her idea, Hedgeman began recruiting interested classmates during the summer of 1907.<ref name="McNealey19">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 19.</ref>

Eventually, nine women including Hedgeman were instrumental in organizing Alpha Kappa Alpha in the fall of 1907.<ref name=Ross-166/><ref name="McNealey19"/> With Hedgeman serving as the temporary chairperson,<ref name=delta/> the women wrote the sorority's constitution, devised the motto, chose the favorite colors, and named the sorority Alpha Kappa Alpha.<ref name=Ross-166/>  Later in 1908, seven sophomore [[honor student]]s expressed interest in joining and were accepted without initiation.<ref name=Ross-166/><ref name="Parker12">Parker, M., ''Past is Prologue'', p. 12.</ref> The first initiation was held in a wing of Miner Hall on Howard University on February 11, 1909.<ref name=lambdaeta-1>{{cite web |date=2005-04-21 |url=http://www.msstate.edu/org/aka/n08.html |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20061129143342/http://www.msstate.edu/org/aka/n08.html |archivedate=2006-11-29 |title=History of AKA |publisher=Lambda Eta Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-30}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref><ref name=akatimeline>{{cite web |url=http://aka1908.com/centennial/pdf/timeline_pdf.pdf |format=PDF |title=Alpha Kappa Alpha Timeline |publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-09}}</ref> On May 25, 1909, Alpha Kappa Alpha held its first "Ivy Week," a celebration that included planting ivy at Miner Hall.<ref name="VCU">{{cite web |url=http://www.studentorg.vcu.edu/thetarho/mowbray.html |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20060829161442/http://www.studentorg.vcu.edu/thetarho/mowbray.html |archivedate=2006-08-29 |title=Ethel Jones Mowbray|publisher=Theta Rho Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-10-27}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref>

===Struggles and incorporation: 1912–1913===
[[File:AKAcertificate.jpg|200px|right|thumb|A 1921 Certificate of Membership from the [[Gamma]] Chapter at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]]<ref name=akatimeline/>]]

Alpha Kappa Alpha continued to grow at Howard. By the end of the 1911–12 school year, there were more than twenty members of the sorority and the organization had become an influential part of student life at Howard.<ref>McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service''.</ref>
Following the annual celebration "Ivy Day" on Howard campus in Spring 1912, founder and former Basileus Nellie Quander learned that several other newly initiated members of the sorority planned to change the colors, letters, and constitution of the sorority, and to make it more active outside Howard University. On January 13, 1913, the entire twenty-two-member undergraduate chapter voted to transform the original Alpha Kappa Alpha into [[Delta Sigma Theta]]. Quander actively worked to maintain the integrity and tenets of Alpha Kappa Alpha.  She, along with the women who had become ΑΚΑs during the four years of the sorority's existence who had since graduated, elected to remain Alpha Kappa Alpha. Quander set up a three-person committee that successfully petitioned to incorporate ΑΚΑ as a perpetual entity. Alpha Kappa Alpha was nationally incorporated on January 29, 1913.<ref>[http://www.aka1908.com/centennial/pdf/quickfacts_pdf.pdf Centennial Celebration Quick Facts]</ref>

The tri-convention—consisting of Alpha Kappa Alpha, Alpha Phi Alpha, and [[Kappa Alpha Psi]]—was held from December 27, through 31, 1940 in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], [[Missouri]].<ref name=akatimeline/><ref>Parker, M., ''Alpha Kappa Alpha Through the Years'', p. 140.</ref>]]

===Expansion and implementation of programs: 1913–1940===
Alpha Kappa Alpha continued to grow nationally. A second chapter at the [[University of Chicago]] was chartered in fall 1913.<ref>{{Wayback |date=20080327063352 |url=http://www2.uic.edu/stud_orgs/greek/akab/beta.htm |title=Beta Chapter History }}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}. Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated. Retrieved January 21, 2008.</ref> The sorority played an active role in voicing concerns of the day. The women, former members who started Delta Sigma Theta, participated in the 1913 [[Women's Suffrage|Women's Suffrage March]].<ref>{{Wayback |date=20080602204321 |url=http://akafarwest.com/main/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=33&Itemid=53 |title=Alpha Kappa Alpha Ushers Centennial Year }}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}. Alpha Kappa Alpha Far Western Region. Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated. January 8, 2008. Retrieved January 30, 2008.</ref> In addition, Alpha Kappa Alpha helped to support members by providing scholarship funds for school and foreign studies.<ref>Jones-Wilson, Faustine Childress. ''Encyclopedia of African-American Education''. Westport, CT: [[Greenwood Press]], 1996. p. 196. ISBN 0-313-28931-X.</ref> Alpha Kappa Alpha began to unite members at the annual [[Alpha Kappa Alpha#Boulé|Boulé]], the sorority's governing body.<ref name=akaterms/> The sorority's pledge was written by Grace Edwards and was adopted by the 1920 Boulé.<ref name="mcnealey329"/> In addition, the sorority's crest was designed by Phyllis Wheatley Waters and accepted in the same Boulé.<ref name="mcnealey329"/> A year later, at the 1921 Boulé, the ''Ivy Leaf'' was designated as "the official organ of Alpha Kappa Alpha," and Founders' Week, paying honor to ΆKΆ's founders was established.<ref name="mcnealey329"/><ref name="Ross167"/> Pearls were first introduced to the sorority in the same year.<ref name="mcnealey329">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 329.</ref> The sorority membership pin was accepted in the following Boulé in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], [[Missouri]].<ref name=Midwestern>{{cite web |url=http://www.aka1908.com/centennial/region-mid-western.html|title=Regional Tributes: Midwestern Region |publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated |accessdate=2006-10-27}}</ref> At the 1947 Boulé, pins for honorary members were designed and approved.<ref name="mcnealey327">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 327.</ref>

On May 10, 1930, Alpha Kappa Alpha, along with the fraternities [[Kappa Alpha Psi]] and [[Omega Psi Phi]] and sororities Delta Sigma Theta and [[Zeta Phi Beta]], formed the [[National Pan-Hellenic Council]] (NPHC) at Howard University.<ref name=NPHC>{{cite web|url=http://www.nphchq.org/mission.htm |title=National Pan-Hellenic Council: About |publisher=NPHC |accessdate=2011-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20100801220537/http://www.nphchq.org:80/mission.htm |archivedate=August 1, 2010 }}</ref> Currently consisting of nine predominately black fraternities and sororities, NPHC promotes interaction through forums, meetings, and other mediums for the exchange of information, and engages in cooperative programming and initiatives through various activities and functions.<ref name=NPHC/>
[[File:Ivyleaf.jpg|140px|thumb|left|A 1934 issue of ''[[Ivy|Ivy Leaf]]'', Alpha Kappa Alpha's official organ<ref name=akaterms/>]]
Throughout the [[Great Migration (African American)|Great Migration]], members assisted the [[Travelers Aid Society]], to help thousands of [[Southern United States|Southern]] Blacks adjust to [[Northern United States|Northern]] society, find housing and navigate around the city.  They also volunteered at the [[Freedman's Hospital]].<ref name="Ross167">Ross, Jr., ''The Divine Nine'', p. 167.</ref>

In April 1933, during the [[Great Depression]], International President Ida Jackson visited All Saints Industrial School in [[Lexington, Mississippi|Lexington]], [[Mississippi]]. She found difficult conditions in the [[Mississippi Delta]]. Some of the teachers did not have an education past the seventh grade. African Americans were trying to make a living sharecropping on plantation land as agricultural prices continued to fall.<ref name="OLDMISS">{{cite web
  |last=Smith
  |first=Susan, L.
  |authorlink=
  |title=Arenia Mallory
  |work=
  |publisher=The [[University of Mississippi]]
  |date=June 2003
  |url=http://www.olemiss.edu/depts/south/ms_encyclopedia/areniamallorysample.htm
  |doi=
  |accessdate=2007-10-20}} {{wayback|url=http://www.olemiss.edu/depts/south/ms_encyclopedia/areniamallorysample.htm |date=20120205182053 }}</ref><ref name="nealey150">McNealey E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 150.</ref> In summer 1934, Ida Jackson initiated the Summer School for Rural Teachers to train future teachers. She worked with a total of 22 student teachers and 243 school children. In addition, she held night classes for 48 adults.<ref name="nealey151">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 151.</ref> By obtaining 2600 books for the school's library, Jackson made it "the largest library owned by white or colored in all Holmes County."<ref name="nealey151"/>

In summer 1938, Ida Jackson focused on poverty and established a regional health clinic. She had acquired $1,000 from the Boulé to fund the project in December 1935.<ref name = "nealey181"/> The clinic evolved into the [[Mississippi Health Project]], with Dr. [[Dorothy Boulding Ferebee]] appointed as the director.<ref name="nealey181">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 181.</ref>

The Mississippi Health Project brought primary medical care to the rural Black population across the state for six summers.<ref name=NIH>{{cite web|date=2007-02-19|url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/changingthefaceofmedicine/physicians/biography_109.html
|title=Changing the Face of Medicine: Dr. Dorothy Celeste Boulding Ferebee|publisher=National Institutes of Health|accessdate=2007-09-28}}</ref><ref name=programs/> The program has been recognized as the first mobile health clinic in the United States, assisting approximately 15,000 people in the Mississippi Delta.<ref name="parker87"/> The project was noted for helping to decrease cases [[diphtheria]] and [[smallpox]] in the region and to improve nutritional and dental practices throughout rural Mississippi.<ref name="Balance">{{cite book
  |last=More
  |first=Ellen S.
  |authorlink=
  |title=Restoring the Balance: Women Physicians and the Profession of Medicine, 1850–1995
  |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]]
  |year=2001
  |doi=
  |isbn=0-674-00567-8
  |page=167 }}</ref><ref name="PLEAID">{{cite web
  |last=Dixon
  |first=Kenneth
  |authorlink=
  |title=AKA seeking charter for new millennium
  |work=
  |publisher=[[Albion College]]'s ''The Pleiad''
  |date=December 3, 1999
  |url=http://www.albion.edu/pleiad/New%20Archives%202003/Dec31999/news.htm
  |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20060914185241/http://www.albion.edu/pleiad/New+Archives+2003/Dec31999/news.htm
  |archivedate=2006-09-14
  |doi=
  |accessdate=2007-10-20}}</ref>

Led by incorporator Norma Elizabeth Boyd, the sorority created the National Non-Partisan Lobby on Civil and Democratic Rights (NPC) in 1938, later renamed the National Non-Partisan Council on Public Affairs. It was the first full-time [[U.S. Congress|congressional]] [[lobbying|lobby]] for minority group civil rights.<ref>{{cite book
  |last=Collier-Thomas
  |first=Bettye
  |authorlink=
  |title=Sisters in the Struggle: African-American Women in the Civil Rights-Black Power Movement
  |publisher=[[NYU]] Press
  |year=2001
  |doi=
  |isbn=0-8147-1603-2
  |page=32 }}</ref><ref name = "nealey157"/> Throughout the organization's life, the Non-Partisan Council worked with the [[NAACP]], [[National Urban League]], The United Office and Professional Workers of America, The National Association of Graduate Nurses, the American Federation of Churches, the Colored Women's Club, the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters and Auxiliary, and the New York Voter's League.<ref name="Parker195">Parker, M., ''Past is Prologue'', p. 195.</ref> The NPC was dissolved on July 15, 1948, by twelfth Supreme Basileus Edna Over Gray-Campbell.<ref name="nealey157">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 157.</ref><ref name="nealey157"/> A year later, Alpha Kappa Alpha was the first sorority to apply for life membership in the [[NAACP]].<ref>McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 125.</ref>

To replace the NPC, in August 1945, Alpha Kappa Alpha established the American Council on Human Rights (ACHR). The council made recommendations to the government concerning [[civil rights]] legislation.<ref name="MCNeal158">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 158.</ref> The ACHR was proposed at the 1946 Boulé.<ref name="MCNeal158"/> In October 1946, Alpha Kappa Alpha was the first sorority to obtain observer status at the [[United Nations]].<ref>McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 126.</ref> On January 25, 1948, Delta Sigma Theta, Zeta Phi Beta, [[Sigma Gamma Rho]] sororities and Alpha Phi Alpha and [[Phi Beta Sigma]] fraternities were charter members of the ACHR.<ref name="MCNeal159">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 159.</ref> Kappa Alpha Psi later was included in March 1949.<ref name="MCNeal160">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 160.</ref><ref name="parker101">Parker, M., ''In the Eye of the Beholder'', p. 101.</ref>

On September 1, 1945, Alpha Kappa Alpha established The National Health Office in [[New York City]].<ref name="parker87">Parker, M., ''In the Eye of the Beholder'', p. 87.</ref> The National Health Office coordinated activities with local chapters and worked with the ACHC to promote health initiatives before [[U.S. Congress|Congress]], increase the number of student [[nurse]]s, and improve the state of health programs at [[HBCU|historically Black Colleges and Universities]].<ref name="parker88">Parker, M., ''In the Eye of the Beholder'', p. 88.</ref> The National Health Office was dissolved in 1951, as its goals were incorporated into the sorority's international program.<ref name="parker89">Parker, M., ''In the Eye of the Beholder'', p. 89.</ref>

===Civil rights and educational training: 1950–1970===
Throughout the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, members helped to sponsor job training, reading enrichment, heritage and youth programs. By encouraging youth to improve math, science, and reading skills, the sorority continued a legacy of community service and pledged to enrich the lives of others. Financially, Alpha Kappa Alpha expanded funding for projects in 1953 through the creation and trademark of a fashion show called Fashionetta<sup>TM</sup>.<ref name="mcnealey327"/><ref name="AKADBO">{{cite web |url=
http://aka-dbo.org/programs.htm|title=Delta Beta Omega Chapter's Programs|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha's Delta Beta Omega Chapter|accessdate=2007-10-24 |archiveurl = //web.archive.org/web/20031010020338/http://aka-dbo.org/programs.htm |archivedate = October 10, 2003}}</ref> Politically, ACHR continued lobbying for equality concerning civil rights during the 1950s and 1960s. According to Collier-Thomas, the ACHR drew attention to legislation concerning education, transportation, employment, and improving equality in the [[armed forces]] and public places.<ref>Collier-Thomas, Bettye; Vincent P. Franklin (2001). ''Sisters in the Struggle: African-American Women in the Civil Rights-Black Power Movement''. New York City: NYU Press. p. 32.</ref> The ACHR participated in filing civil rights cases in [[amicus curiae]] with ''[[Bolling v. Sharpe]]'' and 1954's ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]''.<ref name="IvyLeafArch">[http://academic.lexisnexis.com/documents/upa_cis/1336_TheIvyLeaf.pdf ''Ivy Leaf'': 1921–1998 Microfiche Guide] p. 15 (xv) Published by the United Publications of America, 2000.</ref> However, as a whole, ACHR voted to dissolve operations in 1963.<ref name="IvyLeafArch"/>

Alpha Kappa Alpha contributed programs for inner city youth by capitalizing on political gains in the [[White House]]. On August 20, 1964, President [[Lyndon Johnson]] signed the [[Economic Opportunity Act]], which allowed the creation of the [[Job Corps]].<ref name="McNealey132">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 132.</ref> The sorority wanted to operate a job training center for students. Led by president Julia Purnell, ΆKΆ negotiated with the [[Office of Economic Opportunity]] to operate a women's center from October 1964 to January 1965.<ref name="McNealey132"/> Alpha Kappa Alpha was awarded a [[US$]]4 million grant to operate the [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]] Job Corps on February 12, 1965, becoming the first sorority to operate a federal job training center.<ref name=programs/><ref name="McNealey132"/>  Beginning in 1965, the Cleveland Job Corps trained female high school dropouts, aged 16 to 21, with job and educational skills. In 1976, the Cleveland Job Corps accepted males.<ref name=programs/> The sorority operated the Cleveland Job Corps until 1995.<ref name="clevelandencyclopedia">{{cite web |url=http://ech.case.edu/ech-cgi/article.pl?id=CJC|title=Encyclopedia of Cleveland History: Cleveland Job Corps|publisher=[[Case Western Reserve University]]|accessdate=2007-10-20}}</ref>

The sorority educated the community through highlighting the accomplishments of notable individuals by publishing ''The Heritage Series'' between 1968 and 1972.<ref name=akatimeline/> These [[pamphlets]] were a series of biographies of top African-American women. Altogether, the entire collection contained "Women in the [[Judiciary]]," "Women in [[Politics]]," "Women in [[Medicine]]," "Women in [[Business]]," and "Women in [[Dentistry]]."<ref name="pamphlet">{{cite web|url=http://gozips.uakron.edu/~rmberry/History.html#1_9_6_0__-__1_9_8_0 |title=Chapter History |publisher=Epsilon Mu Omega Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated |accessdate=2007-10-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20060508201743/http://gozips.uakron.edu:80/~rmberry/History.html |archivedate=May 8, 2006 }}</ref> Alpha Kappa Alpha also donated $20,000 for preserving [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]'s [[Martin Luther King, Jr., National Historic Site#King Birth Home|birthplace]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], in the early 1970s.<ref>Parker, M., ''In the Eye of the Beholder'', p. 107.</ref> In 1978, during the sorority's seventieth anniversary, the Memorial Window at Howard University was dedicated to the founders of Alpha Kappa Alpha.  Surviving founders Lavinia Norman and Norma Boyd attended the celebration of unveiling the Memorial Window, designed by Lois Mailou Jones.<ref name="McN330">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 330.</ref>

===Bridging toward the twenty-first century: 1980–2007===

Soon after the sorority's 75th anniversary, Alpha Kappa Alpha contributed funds to decrease Africa's poverty with the establishment of African Village Development Program (AVDP).<ref name="McNealey185">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 185.</ref> As a conjoint program with [[Africare]], the sorority sought to decrease poverty in African villages.<ref name="programs"/><ref name="McNealey185"/> In collaboration with the [[International Foundation for Education and Self-Help]] (IFESH), the sorority built ten schools in [[South Africa]] after [[apartheid]] ended, and it donated computer technology to the region.<ref name="programs"/><ref name="McNealey186">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 186.</ref>

Throughout the 1990s, the sorority continued to provide after-school mentoring programs, such as ON TRACK.<ref name="programs"/> ON TRACK, an acronym which stands for "Organizing, Nurturing, Team building, Respecting, Achieving, Counseling and Knowing," was designed to help the progress of 20,000 third graders who were at-risk of failing their education.<ref name="McNealey153"/> Sponsored by [[Daimler Chrysler]], ON TRACK was designated to "improve communication, academics, physical and emotional health, peer leadership, etiquette, and interpersonal relationships."<ref name="programs"/><ref name="McNealey153">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 153.</ref> In addition, programs such as the
Ivy Reading AKAdemy and Young Authors Program improved elementary reading comprehension skills, while P.I.M.S. highlighted programs in math and science.<ref name="programs"/>

===Lawsuits, forensic audits, and IRS review of former president===
On June 20, 2009, eight Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority members filed a complaint in D.C. Superior Court demanding that International President Barbara McKinzie be fired for improper use of sorority funds and the money be returned to the sorority.<ref>{{cite news|first=James|last=Wright|title=AKA Battles Internal Discord|date=2009-08-13|publisher=New Journal and Guide|url=http://www.njournalg.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=149:aka-battles-internal-discord&catid=41:national-news&Itemid=74|work=The New Journal & Guide Online|accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> The lawsuit claimed that Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated's Executive Board approved the spending of substantial amounts on McKinzie's costs of living, including commissioning an expensive wax model of McKinzie. In response, McKinzie denied the allegations, describing them as "without merit."  The memberships of the eight AKAs who filed the complaint were revoked by the sorority but later forced to be reinstated by a judge.<ref>"Members sue AKA president, cite $900K wax statue", ''Chicago Sun Times'', July 29, 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.friendsoftheweepingivy.com/PDF/PinkGreenVsBAM.pdf]</ref><ref>[http://www.friendsoftheweepingivy.com/PDF/Shackelford_Letter.pdf Shackleford Letter]</ref><ref>http://kollegekidd.com/news/judge-orders-alpha-kappa-alpha-to-reinstate-8-suspended-members/</ref>

In February 2010, the Superior Court of the District of Columbia dismissed the lawsuit.<ref>[http://seattletimes.com/html/nationworld/2010970167_apussororitystatuespat.html Judge dismisses suit against oldest black sorority] {{wayback|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/nationworld/2010970167_apussororitystatuespat.html |date=20141103013147 }}</ref><ref>[http://washington.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/2010/02/01/daily31.html Alpha Kappa Alpha lawsuit dismissed]</ref> On August 18, 2011, the District of Columbia Court of Appeals reversed the previous decision.<ref>[http://www.friendsoftheweepingivy.com/PDF/Appeal%20Decision%2010-CV-220_MTD%5B1%5D.pdf%208%2018%202011.pdf]</ref><ref>[http://www.fileden.com/files/2007/7/31/1311456//AKAReversal.pdf]</ref>

On March 22, 2012, a forensic audit of Alpha Kappa Alpha's 2010 financial records revealed troubling concerns with past president, Barbara McKinzie's development and access to a "secret" bank account. The audit of the sorority led to findings that supported the claims in the previous lawsuit. The audit also found two former officials continued to use sorority credit cards after their service ended, failing to appropriately document charges. Another lawsuit against the organization, the former president McKinzie and other officials contained similar allegations. The audit found that McKinzie and the other officials secretly created a second set of financial books to get around the sorority's accounting policies. According to the audit, "(n)early $1.7 million in payments were made to the former president, Barbara McKinzie, without authorization. Approximately $282,000 in credit card charges on a second set of books appear to be fraudulent, including personal charges the sorority wasn't reimbursed for."<ref name="Audit pdf">[http://www.fileden.com/files/2007/7/31/1311456/Audit.pdf Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc., Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplemental Information, Year Ended December 31, 2010.]</ref>

Also the sorority's tax returns were audited by the Internal Revenue Service. The audit was expected to be concluded sometime in January 2012.<ref name="Audit pdf" />

===Hazing death lawsuit===
On September 9, 2002, pledges Kristin High (22 years old mother of one) and Kenitha Saafir (24 years old) from California State University – Los Angeles (CSULA), were pronounced dead as a result of an illegal pledging ritual. The women were instructed by members of Alpha Kappa Alpha to perform a series of activities blindfolded on Dockweiler State Beach when a high tide came and eventually drowned both of them.  The next day when sorority members brought Kristin's car and cellphone to her mother, she noticed Kristin's pledge journal suddenly missing and numbers deleted from her cellphone. Prior to Kristin's death, Kristin's mother encouraged her to fully disassociate herself from the sorority after Kristin discussed the unsisterly behaviors displayed by members of AKA such as disrespecting pledges and forcing them to run late night errands for AKA members. A year after the tragic incident, the families of the deceased settled with Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Incorporated after filing a $100 million wrongful death lawsuit. The sorority initially denied having an active chapter at CSULA in an effort to deny responsibility for the deaths but the court dismissed their claim and held the whole sorority accountable.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.laweekly.com/news/drowning-deaths-remembered-2138857| work= LA Weekly| title= Drowning deaths remembered| first = Christine| last= Pelisek | date= September 23, 2004}}</ref>

===Alpha Chapter hazing lawsuit===
Two Howard University seniors filed a lawsuit against Alpha Kappa Alpha Incorporated in 2013.  The women accused the sorority of barring them from membership through the most prestigious chapter of the sorority, Alpha Chapter, despite being "legacies" (their mothers were members of the sorority) and in retaliation for reporting illegal hazing. The mothers eventually had their AKA membership revoked for supporting their daughters in the litigation process against the sorority.  In the lawsuit, the women stated that as prospective members of the Alpha Chapter they were verbally abused by women of the sorority, could not wear sorority colors or any colors that could be blended into pink or green, they could not wear pearls, they were forced to run errands and buy items for sorority members,  they could not socialize with their non-AKA friends, they were often humiliated in front of other students, they could not eat at a popular lunch spot on campus, they could not use the same doors as sorority members, and at one point they had to call their "big sisters" daily or suffer some type of consequence.  The women were denied their only opportunity to join the Alpha Chapter of the sorority before they graduated because the chapter was suspended from bringing in new members following an investigation of hazing allegations their previous eligible years.<ref>http://diverseeducation.com/article/66460/</ref>

Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated. October 2005.</ref> However, Clinton later declined initiation into the organization due to the sorority's exclusive requirement preventing acceptance into other [[NPHC|Pan-Hellenic]] organizations, and desired her membership in Alpha Kappa Alpha to be "non-exclusive."<ref name=hillary/><ref name="celebrate">{{cite news |last=Bogues |first=Austin |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/07/14/sorority-celebrates-michelle-obamas-acceptance/ | title=Sorority Celebrates Michelle Obama's Acceptance | work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 14, 2008 |accessdate=April 21, 2009| archiveurl= //web.archive.org/web/20090415141632/http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/07/14/sorority-celebrates-michelle-obamas-acceptance/?| archivedate= 15 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

===Membership interest and intake===
The Ivy Leaf Pledge Club was the official pledge club of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated.<ref>Parker, M., ''In the Eye of the Beholder'', p. 2.</ref> Potential candidates who were interested in joining the sorority would join the pledge club before being inducted into the sorority.<ref name=LZ>{{cite web|date=2007-02-19|url=http://www.aka1908.com/present/membership/prospectivemembers/|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20080509023246/http://www.aka1908.com/present/membership/prospectivemembers/|archivedate=2008-05-09
|title=Prospective Members|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated — Lambda Zeta|accessdate=2007-05-27}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref>

[[File:Ivyleafclub.jpg|left|200px|thumb|An "Ivy Leaf Pledge Club" located at [[Wilberforce University]] in 1922]]

In ''Our Kind of People: Inside America's Upper Class,'' [[Lawrence Otis Graham]] tells of his aunt's experience in joining the Ivy Pledge Club: {{cquote|We had to learn a lot more about the historic beginnings of the AKAs, and we did it by writing long letters of application to the Ivy Leaf Pledge Club—the senior wing of the sorority that regulated the admissions process—and then attending monthly meetings where the older students tutored us on the history.<ref name="log">{{cite book
  |last=Graham
  |first=Lawrence Otis
  |title=Our Kind of People: Inside America's Black Upper Class
  |publisher=[[HarperCollins]] Publishers
  |year=1999
  |location=New York, New York
  |isbn=0-06-018352-7
  |page=96}}</ref>}}
In addition, according to Graham, the sorority would have "Pledge Week", a period where a candidate's grades and behavior were reviewed by chapter members. Candidates who withstood this period were initiated into the sorority.<ref name=log/> Membership interest is processed by an interest meeting, known as a "rush". After the candidate receives an official letter from the sorority, she can participate in the membership intake process. Prospective members must have a C+ average or better prior to their membership submission, as well as a record of community service. If a prospective member has graduated, that member could be invited to join the sorority at the discretion of the graduate chapter.<ref name=prospective>{{cite web|year=2006|url=http://www.aka1908.com/present/membership/prospectivemembers/
|title=Alpha Kappa Alpha — Prospective Members|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-27 |archiveurl = //web.archive.org/web/20070316003854/http://www.aka1908.com/present/membership/prospectivemembers/ |archivedate = March 16, 2007}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref>

The leadership of the sorority in the early years was derived from three separate groups—the original group, the sophomores and the incorporators, who together were known as "The Twenty Pearls."<ref name=akaterms/><ref name=AKA-Leaders>{{cite web |url=http://www.aka1908.com/past/ |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20080805040513/http://www.aka1908.com/past/ |archivedate=2008-08-05 |title=AKA Leadership |publisher=aka1908.com |accessdate=2006-10-07}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref> The Executive Director position has been held by eight members since the office's creation on October 9, 1949.<ref>McNealey E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 257.</ref>

===Boulé===
{{Main article|List of Alpha Kappa Alpha Boulés}}
The Boulé{{efn-ua|The word ''boulé'', derived from ancient Greek [[Boule (ancient Greece)|βουλή]] and originally referring to a council of nobles advising a king, is also used by the African-American professional organization [[Sigma Pi Phi]].}} is the regulating institution of the sorority and currently meets every two years.<ref name=akaterms/> Throughout the years, notable individuals such as civil rights activists Martin Luther King, Jr. and [[Roy Wilkins]] were speakers at past Boulé conferences.<ref name=akatimeline/>

===Regions===
[[File:Akaregion.gif|200px|thumb|right|The nine regions of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority within the United States<ref name=regions2>{{cite web |url=https://akawebnet.aka1908.net/eweb/DynamicPage.aspx?webcode=CL|title=Chapter Locator|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-16}}</ref>]]

==National programs==

===Educational Advancement Foundation===
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:EAFlogo.png|150px|thumb|Official logo of the Educational Advancement Foundation]] -->
Alpha Kappa Alpha's Educational Advancement Foundation (EAF) is a separate and [[tax-exempt]] branch of the sorority, which "provide[s] financial support to individuals and organizations engaged in lifelong learning."<ref name=aboutEAF>{{cite web |url=http://www.akaeaf.org/about/|title=About Educational Advancement Foundation|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated — Educational Advancement Foundation|accessdate=2007-05-16| archiveurl= //web.archive.org/web/20070613225635/http://www.akaeaf.org/about/| archivedate= 13 June 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The foundation awards academic scholarships (for undergraduate members of the sorority, as well as non-members), [[fellow]]ships, and [[Grant (money)|grants]] for community service.<ref name=PASEAF>{{cite web |url=http://www.akaeaf.org/programsandinitiatives/|title=AKA Educational Advancement Foundation Programs|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated — Educational Advancement Foundation|accessdate=2007-05-16| archiveurl= //web.archive.org/web/20070516062245/http://www.akaeaf.org/programsandinitiatives/| archivedate= 16 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

====History and donations====
The foundation was the brainchild of Constance Holland, the sister of former Alpha Kappa Alpha International President Dr. Barbara Phillips, in 1978.  The foundation had official beginnings in 1980 and the sorority donated US$10,000 for the project. Eight years later, the organization first awarded $10,000 to fourteen students.  In 1991, EAF first awarded mini-grants to community organizations.  In 1998, EAF provided the first Youth Partners Accessing Capital (PAC) award to an undergraduate member.

At the organization's twentieth anniversary in 2000, EAF published ''Perpetuating Our Posterity: A Blueprint for Excellence.'' The book served as a comprehensive history of the organization and as a source of advice for other beginning philanthropies. EAF went online with a [[website]] in 2003.

The organization celebrated a silver anniversary in [[Nassau, Bahamas]], in 2005. EAF is incorporated into International President Barbara A. McKinzie's centennial program for funding under '''E'''xcellent '''S'''cholarly '''P'''erformance.  Overall, EAF has donated more than $200,000 in grants and awarded 1,400 students with scholarships.<ref name=AKAEAF>{{cite web |url=http://aka1908.com/eaf/ |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20080621150132/http://www.aka1908.com/eaf/ |archivedate=2008-06-21|title=Making a Difference — Educational Advancement Foundation|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-16}}</ref> Other major donors to EAF include [[Continental Airlines]] and [[Northern Trust]].<ref name=donorsEAF>{{cite web |url=http://www.akaeaf.org/donors/|title=Donors — Educational Advancement Foundation|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated — Educational Advancement Foundation|accessdate=2007-05-16| archiveurl= //web.archive.org/web/20070621154831/http://www.akaeaf.org/donors/| archivedate= 21 June 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

===Ivy Acres===
Ivy Acres will be a retirement center located in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]].  The retirement center is sponsored by Senior Residences, Incorporated, a subsidiary of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority.<ref name=business/> Ivy Acres will be one of the first retirement centers founded by African-Americans and [[minorities]] in the United States.  It will offer assisted or individual living for individuals who are over fifty-five, regardless of background, ethnicity or religion.<ref name=business/><ref name="midatlantic">{{cite web |year=2007|url=http://www.aka1908.com/centennial/region-mid-atlantic.html |title=AKA Centennial Regions: Mid-Atlantic|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-11-05| archiveurl= 
http://web.archive.org/web/20070930013007/http://aka1908.com/centennial/region-mid-atlantic.html| archivedate= 30 September 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Barbara K. Phillips, former Vice-President and Project Coordinator for Senior Residences, Incorporated, explains the purpose of Ivy Acres, "We determined that there is a need out there, but this will be open to all. We want to be diverse, we want to be multicultural. Anyone who wants to come will be welcome."<ref name="business">{{cite news |first=Marc |last=Barnes |authorlink= |title=
Long-planned continuing care complex draws closer to reality |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triad/stories/2002/10/07/story6.html |work=The Business Journal |publisher=American City Business Journals|date=October 4, 2002|accessdate=2007-06-19}}</ref>

The gated community will be located on a {{convert|48|acre|m2|sing=on}} site. The planning for Ivy Acres cost approximately $32 million USD.<ref name=business/> In addition, according to ''[[Business Wire]]'', Ivy Acres will comprise "188 independent residential units, which will be both apartments and cottages, forty assisted-living apartments and twenty private accommodations for skilled nursing care."<ref name=business/> Residents are expected to pay $1,890 to $2,890 per month for services.<ref name=business/> [[File:Alphaepsilon.jpg|200px|left|thumb|Alpha Kappa Alpha's Alpha Epsilon chapter at [[Virginia State University]] in 1994.]]

===Ivy Reading AKAdemy===
The Ivy Reading AKAdemy provides programs that encourage the entire community to become involved.  The  concept serves as an educational and human resource center for programs provided by Alpha Kappa Alpha. Working with [[No Child Left Behind Act|No Child Left Behind]] in mind, "The Ivy Reading AKAdemy," a reading initiative, focuses on early learning and mastery of basic reading skills by the end of third grade. The Ivy Reading AKAdemy has a $1.5 million proposal pending with the [[United States Department of Education]] to fund a three-year nationwide after-school demonstration project in low-performing, economically deprived inner city schools in 16 sites within the continental United States.<ref name=programs/>

===Leadership Fellows Program===
The Leadership Fellows Program is a fully funded event in which thirty Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority sophomore and junior undergraduate members worldwide are individually trained for professional leadership roles. In addition, the fellows contribute to community service for one week. One of the selection criteria is that members must have at least a 3.0 [[GPA]].<ref name=leaders>{{cite web |url=http://aka1908.com/future/leadership/|title=Leadership Fellows Program |publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-11 |archiveurl = //web.archive.org/web/20070625052137/http://www.aka1908.com/future/leadership/ |archivedate = June 25, 2007}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref> The program initially was planned in 1978. In the following year, the first program was held in [[Indiana]] with twenty-nine students.<ref name=programs>{{cite web |url=http://aka1908.com/centennial/pdf/programs_pdf.pdf|format=PDF
|title=Alpha Kappa Alpha National Programs |publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-11}}</ref> Various cities around the United States have held the Leadership Fellows Program. In the past, Alpha Kappa Alpha has sponsored the event through the Educational Advancement Foundation.  Also, the program has been financed by [[Pillsbury Company|Pillsbury]], [[Tyson Foods]], [[Johnson & Johnson]], and most recently [[General Electric]].<ref name=applicationleaders>{{cite web |url=http://aka1908.com/pdf/lf07-form.pdf |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20080529192444/http://aka1908.com/pdf/lf07-form.pdf |archivedate=2008-05-29|format=PDF|title=2007 Leadership Fellows Program Application|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2007-05-11}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref><ref name=generalelectric>{{cite web |url=http://www.aka1908.com/news/geleadershipfellows/|title=Leadership Fellows Program Adds GE as Partner|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2008-03-04 |archiveurl = //web.archive.org/web/20080406182417/http://www.aka1908.com/news/geleadershipfellows/ |archivedate = April 6, 2008}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aka1908.com/future/leadership/|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20080618093926/http://aka1908.com/future/leadership/|archivedate=2008-06-18|title=Alpha Kappa Alpha Leadership Fellows Program|publisher=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated|accessdate=2010-04-23}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref>

===Partnerships in Mathematics and Science===
Partnerships in Mathematics and Science (PIMS) began in Eva Evans's administration in 1994, and was a part of the SPIRIT program during the [[Linda White]] administration.<ref name="mcnealey152">McNealey, E., ''Pearls of Service'', p. 152.</ref> Eva Evans mentioned the need for a math and science program, "As a college sorority, we've always advanced an educational agenda. We always had high GPA requirements.  And more than ever, we're pushing the importance of math and science for our girls.  We need more black women in those fields."<ref name="log2">Graham, L., ''Our Kind of People'', p. 91.</ref> The program's purpose is to increase the successes of youth in mathematics and science, as well as technology. Campaigns to highlight the program's importance were sponsored by the [[National Science Foundation]] and historically black colleges from across the country.<ref name="mcnealey152"/> Several chapters provided two-week math and science summer camps on college and day school campuses, which consisted of hands-on-learning through laboratory interactions, field trips to important sites, youth camps, and speeches from influential experts in specific areas of studies.<ref name=programs/><ref name="McNealey153"/> For example, a PIMS program at Park Street Elementary School in [[Marietta, Georgia]], consisted of third through fifth grade girls and provided educational field trips in order to stimulate involvement in math and science.<ref name=NI/><ref name=marietta>{{cite web |url=http://www.marietta-city.k12.ga.us/parkstreet/html/ourschool.htm |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20070812152652/http://www.marietta-city.k12.ga.us/parkstreet/html/ourschool.htm |archivedate=2007-08-12
|title=Park Street Elementary School-Our Programs |publisher=Marietta City Schools|accessdate=2007-05-29}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref> Also, a national P.I.M.S. Olympiad, deriving from knowledge of math and science, in conjunction with the PIMS Community Parade was held at the 58th Boulé in [[Dallas, Texas]].<ref name=programs/><ref name="McNealey153"/>

===Young Authors Program===
In Linda White's administrations, the Young Authors Program was born.  The purpose of the program is to encourage and raise involvement in reading and writing in kindergarten through third grade school children. Each of the ten regions in the sorority had the opportunity to choose a child's story to be published in a two volume anthology entitled, ''The Spirit Within: Voices of Young Authors''.<ref name=programs/> In 2004, twenty children were honored in the first anthology.<ref name=Jet>{{cite news |first=
 |last= |authorlink= |author= |title=Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority focuses on early childhood literacy at 61st AKA National Convention |url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1077/is_n9_v51/ai_18435320 |work=[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] |publisher=Johnson Publishing Company |pages= |page= |date=2004-08-30 |accessdate=2007-05-31  |quote=}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref>  The authors were recognized and performed book signings in the 2004 and 2006 Boulés.<ref name=programs/> At the 2004 Boulé in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], former [[United States Department of Education|Department of Education]] Secretary [[Rod Paige]] attended. On July 15, 2004, First Lady [[Laura Bush]] spoke on the Ivy AKAdemy's dedication to reading initiatives, "Teaching our children to read is the most critical educational priority facing our country. Children who do not learn to read by third grade continue to find reading a challenge throughout their lives. These expectations increase in amount and complexity each year."<ref name=Jet/><ref name=LauraBush>{{cite web |date=2004-07-15|url=http://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2004/07/20040715-11.html|title=
Mrs. Bush's Remarks at Alpha Kappa Alpha National Convention|publisher=Office of the First Lady|accessdate=2007-05-31}}</ref>

The '''Association for the Protection and Defense of Women's Rights in Saudi Arabia''' is a [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] [[Non-governmental organization]] founded to provide activism for [[Women's rights in Saudi Arabia|women's rights]]. It was founded by [[Wajeha al-Huwaider]] and Fawzia Al-Uyyouni, and grew out of a 2007 movement to gain women the right to drive. The association is not officially licensed by the government of Saudi Arabia, and has been warned not to mount demonstrations. In a 2007 interview, al-Huwaider described the goals:http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/2383.htm
The association will consist of a number of leagues, with each league pursuing a different issue or right... representation for women in shari'a courts; setting a [minimum] age for girls' marriages; allowing women to take care of their own affairs in government agencies and allowing them to enter government buildings; protecting women from domestic violence, such as physical or verbal violence, or keeping her from studies, work, or marriage, or forcing her to divorce…
The association's first campaign gathered signatures to petition [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]] to allow women to drive.http://www.aafaq.org/english/aafaq_today.aspx?id_news=116 The petition was ignored. In 2008, the association launched a "No to the Oppression of Women" campaign. The campaign recorded Saudi women speaking about the oppression or violence to which they had been subjected, with complete assurance of confidentiality and put the recordings on [[YouTube]]. The association described its campaign as giving victims a voice.http://www.aafaq.org/english/aafaq_today.aspx?id_news=151 == References == {{Portal|Saudi Arabia|Feminism}} {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =2008 Human Rights Report: Saudi Arabia| work =| publisher =[[United States State Department]]| date =2009-02-25| url =http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/nea/119126.htm | doi =| accessdate =2011-05-23 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5yu1Mt6Uf |archivedate=2011-05-23 |deadurl=no }} }} [[Category:Women's rights organizations]] [[Category:Women's rights in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Human rights organisations based in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:2011–12 Saudi Arabian protests]]
