{{peacock|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox Fraternity | letters = ΣΛΓ| name = Sigma Lambda Gamma| motto = Culture is Pride, Pride is Success (''Cultura es Orgullo, Orgullo es Exito'')| crest = [[File:Sigma-Lambda-Gamma crest.jpg|center|180px|The official crest of Sigma Lambda Gamma.]]| founded = {{start date and years ago|1990|4|9}}| type = [[List of social fraternities and sororities|Cultural]] | scope = National | address = 125 E. Zeller Street Suites D & E | city = North Liberty | state = Iowa | country = USA | chapters = 135 undergrad, 17 colonies, 25 alumnae associations | colors = {{color box|#FF1493}} Shocking Pink
{{color box|#800080}} Majestic Purple | free_label = Nickname | free = SLG| homepage = [http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/ Sigma Lambda Gamma Website] | birthplace = [[University of Iowa]] | flower = Pink [[Rose]] | Newsletter= ''La Mensajera''| symbol = Purple Panther | stone = Purple [[Amethyst]]| }} '''Sigma Lambda Gamma''' '''(ΣΛΓ)''' (also known as '''Gammas''' or '''SLG''') is a historically [[Latina]]-based national [[Fraternities and sororities in North America|sorority]] with multicultural membership founded on April 9, 1990, at the [[University of Iowa]] in [[Iowa City, Iowa]] by five collegiate women who wanted an organization to empower all women. The sorority focuses on five principles - academics, community service, cultural awareness, social interaction, and morals and ethics - to unite their members as "hermanas por vida" (sisters for life). Since its beginnings, Sigma Lambda Gamma has created national national progonal programmings to empower their members and women of the community, such as the Young Women’s Leadership Program and [[Emotional Intelligence]]. They have also partnered up with other organizations to improve political, educational, and social conditions in the United States. A sisterhood of over 8,000 members, the sorority believes that ''Culture is Pride, Pride is Success'' and explores the richness in the traditions of different cultures. This encompasses the cultural heritages of Native Americans (North, Central and South), Africans, Europeans, Asians and their multiple and interesting mixtures. They celebrate the diversity of the backgrounds of all the members of the sorority,{{cite web| title = About SLG: Our Roots – "Nuestras Raices" | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://sigmalambdagamma.membershipsoftware.org/content.asp?contentid=137| accessdate = 2013-06-04}} representing over 110 nationalities.{{cite web|title=SLG Today |author= |publisher= |date= |url=http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/today |accessdate=2013-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511141559/http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/today |archivedate=May 11, 2009 }} Today, Sigma Lambda Gamma is the largest and fastest growing multi-cultural organization in chapters and alumnae associations throughout the United States, having expanded to more than 100 universities in less than 20 years. Membership in Sigma Lambda Gamma is open to any woman who meets the membership requirements, regardless of religion, race, or nationality. Women may join through undergraduate chapters at a college or university, or after acquiring a college degree through an alumnae association. The current executive director is Vanessa Jimenez.{{cite web| title = National Headquarters | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/content.asp?contentid=145| accessdate = 2014-06-04}} ==History== ===Creation of Sigma Lambda Gamma and beginnings: 1989–2000=== {{quote box|width=30%|align=right|qalign = center|bgcolor=|quote=''Sigma Lambda Gamma strives to be the premier organization committed to providing a mechanism of empowerment to all women. Through a network of close to 8,000 members from collegiate chapters and alumnae associations located across the United States, it promotes academic excellence and higher education through the sorority's principles: academics, community service, cultural awareness, morals and ethics, social interaction-in our daily lives.'' — Mission Statement{{cite web| title = Mission and Vision | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/content.asp?contentid=140 | accessdate = 2013-06-04}}}} In fall of 1989, a group of women met to form an organization that would provide empowerment to Latina women. With its beginnings at the University of Iowa, the vision was to create a network of academic and social support. Although the first meeting had 19 women, membership fluctuated during the planning process.{{cite web| title = Alpha Chapter History | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.uiowa.edu/~slgalpha/about.html | accessdate = 2013-06-04}} Under the guidance of Esther Materon Arum and Mary Peterson, the members continued to draft a sorority that would be inclusive and empowering to women. A retreat was held to establish the constitution and the purpose of the organization. They also participated in volunteer projects such as the National Association of Chicano Studies (NACS), as well as on-campus programs such as the Leadership Conference. Eventually, only five women remained. These women are Gloria Cuevas, Julieta Maria Miller, Maria Ester Pineda, Danell Marie Riojas, and Guadalupe Temiquel. Despite the decrease in number, the five women continued to polish up the constitution and structure for their sorority as well as keeping with their commitment to the community. On April 9, 1990, the University of Iowa Panhellenic Council officially recognized the organization as a sorority. Sigma Lambda Gamma celebrates this as their founding date. The five women became known as the Five Founding Mothers and would continue to actively establish Sigma Lambda Gamma as the sorority it is today by demonstrating a commitment to being ''Hermanas Por Vida'' (Sisters For Life). The first inductees to the sorority in the spring 1991 term played a vital role in promoting the ideals of the organization on the University of Iowa campus, and helped with the first wave of expansion to the [[University of Michigan]],{{cite web| title = University of Michigan Beta Chapter History| author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.wolverinegammas.com/#!about | accessdate = 2014-05-27}} [[Iowa State University]]{{cite web| title = Iowa State University Gamma Chapter History| author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://stuorg.iastate.edu/gammas/ghistory.html | accessdate = 2014-05-27}} and the [[University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign]].{{cite web| title = University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign Delta Chapter History| author = | publisher = | date = |url =https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sigma-Lambda-Gamma-Delta-Chapter/202247606496796?id=202247606496796&sk=info| accessdate = 2014-05-27}} They expanded outside of the Midwest with the chartering of chapters at the [[University of South Florida]] in Tampa, Florida;{{cite web| title = University of South Florida Mu Chapter History| author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://thinkpinklovepurple.com/about_us/| accessdate = 2014-05-27}} [[California State University-Dominguez Hills]] in Carson, California; and the [[University of Texas at Austin]] at Austin, Texas.{{cite web| title = University of Texas at Austin Xi Chapter History| author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.texasgammas.org/#!about-slg| accessdate = 2014-05-27}} With time, it eventually expanded to other campuses, becoming one of the fastest growing fraternal organization in the United States. In keeping up with the expansion and to create more unity among chapters, a national headquarter was established at 900 West Penn Street, [[North Liberty, Iowa|North Liberty]], Iowa. They later move to their current address at 125 E. Zeller Street Suites D & E, North Liberty, Iowa. Along with housing national records and staff, it is also home to the sorority's national quarterly publication, ''La Mensajera.''{{cite web| title = La Mensajara | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/content.asp?contentid=168 | accessdate = 2014-06-04}} The Omega Chapter was later established to recognize and pay respect to deceased sisters.{{cite web| title = Omega Chapter | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/content.asp?contentid=149 | accessdate = 2014-06-04}} ===Development of national programming and "Drive to 25": 2000–present=== As the sorority grew, Sigma Lambda Gamma's membership became more multicultural. In acknowledging this, the organization, which was a part of the [[National Association of Latino Fraternal Organizations]] from January 2001 to May 2010, left due to a desire for autonomy and due to their increasing multicultural membership.{{cite web | url = https://www.facebook.com/notes/sigma-lambda-gamma-national-sorority-inc/nalfo-membership-status/469957421223 | title=SLG's NALFO membership status | accessdate = 2011-02-21}} The sorority celebrated their 100th and 101st chapter simultaneously with the addition of the Theta Delta chapter at [[Columbia University]] and the Iota Delta chapter at [[Millikin University]] in 2010, having expanding to more than 100 chapters in 20 years.{{cite web| title =Sigma Lambda Gamma Reaches Charter Milestone| author = | publisher = | date = 2010-08-02 |url =https://www.facebook.com/notes/sigma-lambda-gamma-national-sorority-inc/sigma-lambda-gamma-reaches-charter-milestone/469957411223| accessdate = 2014-06-03}} {{quote box|width=30%|align=left|qalign = center|bgcolor=|quote=''Recognizing its responsibility to the progression of a positive global community, the sorority stresses the importance of morals, ethics, and education in the daily lives of its members, so that they serve the needs of their neighbors through a mutual respect and understanding of their various cultures.'' — Vision Statement}} While chapters have always organized local programmings on their respective campuses,{{cite web| title = FAMU Unidos and Sigma Lambda Gamma Break the Stereotypes| author = Ward, Jessika| publisher = FAMU | date = 2014-10-24 |url =http://www.thefamuanonline.com/news/view.php/852460/FAMU-Unidos-and-Sigma-Lambda-Gamma-Break | accessdate = 2014-12-18}} Sigma Lambda Gamma began to create national programmings to foster more unity. With a strong belief in giving back to the community, they created their Education Foundation, where several programs were created under. In striving to empower all women, as stated in their mission, they established [[Sigma Lambda Gamma#Young Women’s Leadership Program|The Young Women’s Leadership]] program, designed to promote confidence and leadership skills for middle-school aged girls.{{cite web| title = Member Development Program| author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/content.asp?contentid=148 | accessdate = 2013-06-04}}{{cite web| title = SLG Programs | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.slgfoundation.org/programs/ | accessdate = 2013-06-04}} Additionally, in encouraging their members to grow and assess themselves, they started the [[Sigma Lambda Gamma#Emotional Intelligence|Emotional Intelligence]] education program. A scholarship program was also added to support their members in higher education.{{cite web| title = Scholarship Program| author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.slgfoundation.org/programs/scholarship-program/ | accessdate = 2014-06-03}} In 2012, the [[Sigma Lambda Gamma#Panther Dash for Education|Panther Dash For Education]] was created to generate funds that will support scholastic achievement, leadership training, and continue the commitment to lifelong learning and service to the global community for sisters.{{cite web| title = SLG Foundation Panther Dash | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.slgfoundation.org/programs/pantherdash/ | accessdate = 2013-06-04}} A virtual race, sisters are encourage to participate in any run/walk event of their choice and then later upload it to media sites. The sorority has been active in bringing about social changes in the community as well. In hopes of encouraging their members and [[Person of color|youth of color]] to promote positive change, they began a partnership with VotoLatino in 2012, a nonpartisan organization that empowers Latino Millennials to claim a better future for themselves and their community by voting and learning how to make a difference.{{cite web| title = Rep Ur Letters | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.votolatino.org/show-your-letters | accessdate = 2013-06-04}} In the 2014 VotoLatino's RepUrLetters Challenge, in which historically Latino Greek-lettered organizations competed to register voters on their campuses and in their communities, Sigma Lambda Gamma's voter registration efforts accounted for 36% of the total number of voters registered, with the highest number of voters registered.{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc. Declared Winner of Voto Latino’s RepUrLetters Challenge | author = Hedstrom, Lauren| publisher = VotoLatino | date = 2014-11-07 |url =http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/Files/Memos%20and%20Notifications/RUL%20Press%20Release.pdf | accessdate = 2014-11-14}}{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc. Takes the Lead in the RepUrLetters Challenge | author = Fluetsch, Francine| publisher = ULoop | date = 2014-11-26 |url =http://www.uloop.com/news/view.php/143792/Sigma-Lambda-Gamma-National-Sorority-In | accessdate = 2014-12-18}} For their 2013 National Sisterhood Retreat, Sigma Lambda Gamma was honored by the Diosa Nail & Polish company with their colors to commemorate the ''Educate. Engage. Empower.'' theme. Sisters suggested names and voted on it. The two colors are: “Women of Dis-PINK-tion” to reflect their color shocking pink and “On the Prowl” to reflect their color majestic purple as well as their stone, amethyst. Sisters across the nation took part in hosting and participating in community-based events to give back to the community, whether it is coordinating a book drive or volunteering in local [[women's shelter]].{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma celebrates 25th anniversary | author = Moore, Lindsay| publisher = Indiana Daily Students| date = 2014-11-09 |url =http://www.idsnews.com/article/2014/11/sigma-lambda-gamma-celebrates-25th-anniversary | accessdate = 2014-11-14}}{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma to hold first Gamma Gives Back Week | author = Moore, Lindsay| publisher = Indiana Daily Students| date = 2014-11-06 |url =http://www.idsnews.com:8080/article/2014/11/sigma-lambda-gamma-to-hold-first-gamma-gives-back-week | accessdate = 2014-12-14}} ==Gamma Founders== [[File:Sigma Lambda Gamma Founding Mothers.jpg|thumb|right|245px|A [[snapshot (photography)|snapshot]] of the five Founding Mothers of the sorority]] The five Founding Mothers of Sigma Lambda Gamma are: *Gloria Cuevas *Julieta Maria Miller *Maria Ester Pineda *Danell Marie Riojas *Guadalupe Temiquel ==Philanthropies== Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc. supports a variety of charitable organizations as a part of their community service commitment. As a national organization, their main philanthropies are [[Breast Cancer]] Awareness and the TRIO programs. Sorority entities conduct and participate in programming events that are designed to raise awareness and educate the public on these topics. Additionally, chapters also organize local philanthropic projects, such as the raising funds for the [[2013 Moore tornado|2013 Oklahoma tornado disaster]],{{cite web| title = Nebraskans Look for Ways to Help Oklahoma Tornado Victims | author = Onwiler, Jordan| publisher = NTV| date = |url =http://www.nebraska.tv/story/22398675/nebraskans-look-for-ways-to-help-oklahoma-tornado-victims | accessdate = 2013-06-04}}{{cite web| title = Red Cross text-messaging drive dwarfs online fundraisers for Oklahoma | author = Collier, Kevin| publisher = Daily Dot| date = |url =http://www.dailydot.com/society/oklahoma-tornado-fundraiser-red-cross-90999/ | accessdate = 2013-06-04}} adopting a highway,{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma sorority adopts Tucson park | author = Walker, Brandi | publisher = The Daily Wildcat| date = 2015-04-20 |url =http://www.wildcat.arizona.edu/article/2015/04/sigma-lambda-gamma-sorority-adopts-tucson-park| accessdate = 2015-06-21}} and animal shelters.{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma to hold Rent-A-Puppy Fundraiser | author = Rezab, Matthew | publisher = Iowa State Daily| date = 2015-04-08 |url =http://www.iowastatedaily.com/news/article_467e8f0e-dd84-11e4-b205-ffbee8ed943a.html| accessdate = 2015-06-21}} In 2014, they launched their "Gammas Go Red" campaign on social media sites in an effort to raise awareness in the fight against [[Cardiovascular disease|heart disease]] in women.{{cite web| title = Gammas Go Red | author = | publisher = | date = 2014-02-06 |url =https://www.facebook.com/SigmaLambdaGamma/photos/a.77367169132.72118.75707304132/10152183629244133/?type=1 | accessdate = 2013-06-04}} ===Breast Cancer Awareness=== Sigma Lambda Gamma actively support the important societal issue of Breast Cancer Awareness. Their support comes in various avenues: from fundraising campaigns; educational workshops to create awareness; active participation in run/walk events; volunteer participation with organizations; or a combination of these forms. The two primary programs the organization supports in respects to breast cancer awareness include, but are not limited to: [[Susan G. Komen for the Cure]] and [[Y-ME National Breast Cancer Organization]].{{cite web| title = SLG Philanthropy | author = | publisher = | date = |url =http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/content.asp?contentid=141| accessdate = 2013-06-04}} One member shaved her head to raise money for cancer research, eventually topping $2650,{{cite web| title = Graduate student raises $2650 for cancer research | author = Cabrera, Nayeli| publisher = | date = |url =http://hbucollegian.com/?p=10966 | accessdate = 2013-06-04}} while another chapter organized a fashion show.{{cite web| title = All-male Model Lineup Strut Their Stuff to Support Breast Cancer Survivor | author = Mahon, Madeline | publisher = Pipe Dream | date = 2014-11-21 |url =http://www.bupipedream.com/news/44340/all-male-model-lineup-strut-their-stuff-to-support-breast-cancer-survivor/ | accessdate = 2014-12-18}} One chapter organized a ball with the men of [[Phi Beta Sigma]] to raise funds for breast cancer and the [[March of Dimes]].{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma and Phi Beta Sigma host first ever Pink and Blue Ball | author = Barber, Jessica | publisher = The Oklahoma Daily | date = 2015-04-09 |url =http://www.oudaily.com/news/sigma-lambda-gamma-and-phi-beta-sigma-host-first-ever/article_1a8643fa-df06-11e4-93c0-c719cefaf5fd.html | accessdate = 2015-06-21}} In 2014, the sorority raised over $14,000 to donate to 20 different breast cancer research organizations.{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma Sorority Donates Over $14,000 to Breast Cancer | author = | publisher = Sigma Lambda Gamma | date = 2014-11-19 |url = http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/files/Press%20Release_Pink%20Out4.pdf | accessdate = 2014-11-04}} ===TRIO Programs=== Sigma Lambda Gamma supports the [[TRIO (program)|TRIO programs]] for its innovative and proactive stance on the continual education of individuals who otherwise would not have been afforded the education or financial assistance to further their education and livelihood. These programs have become stepping stones for many students within the organization and other affiliates who have benefited to identify and continue secondary education. Chapters have organized local fundraisers to donate to TRIO programs.{{cite web| title = Greek community offers fun while raising money for good causes | author = Boehm, Cassie| publisher = | date = 2014-04-25 |url =http://www.creightonian.com/scene/article_9c434d56-caae-11e3-a42b-0017a43b2370.html | accessdate = 2013-06-04}} ==National programs== To foster more unity, Sigma Lambda Gamma created the Sigma Lambda Gamma Education Foundation, an umbrella philanthropic entity for their national programs. ===Young Women’s Leadership Program=== An eight-week program, the Young Women's Leadership Program introduces young girls to the principles embodied by Sigma Lambda Gamma. Through series of exercises and activities designed to help them learn about themselves and each other along the way, the program is facilitated by members of local Sigma Lambda Gamma Alumnae Associations who serve as mentors and role models for the participants throughout the program and beyond. The goal of the program is to get a head start with young girls to provide them the self-awareness and self-esteem to help them finish their high school education and consider pursuing a college degree upon graduation. As this program is a volunteer effort that takes place outside of the regular school day, the Sigma Lambda Gamma Education Foundation assist programs across the country to provide materials, transportation, food and other program costs for facilitators and participants. ===Panther Dash for Education=== To encourage sisters to mobilize their body as well as give back to the community, Sigma Lambda Gamma created the Panther Dash for Education in 2012. As with all Sigma Lambda Gamma initiatives, the Panther Dash for Education supports the empowerment of women by providing Gammas, friends, and family the opportunity to walk, jog, or run any 5k race of their choice while raising funds to support the SLGEF's Mission and Vision. Sisters are encouraged to upload pictures onto social media websites. To raise funds, sisters can buy packages for the race. Items can include a bib, T-shirt, or water bottle with the sorority's letters and logo. ===Emotional Intelligence=== In Sigma Lambda Gamma’s continuing effort to become the premier women’s organization, the organization launched an educational program for their members based on emotional intelligence, committed to enhancing their members' personal and social competencies. The program encourages members to develop specific skills of emotional intelligence for personal and leadership development. This program is focused on members addressing the needs of the sisterhood in the most timely and effective way. All members complete the EI Profile: An Emotional Intelligence Self-Assessment. Based on the results of this self-assessment, members will have the chance during the academic year to learn more about the nineteen different skills of emotional intelligence. ===Scholarships=== The organization supports their members in higher education by offering annual scholarships. It is only opened to members who have been initiated into the organization and are in good-standing, as defined by Sigma Lambda Gamma policy, who are enrolled as degree-seeking student during the academic year. Sisters who are studying abroad are not eligible. The two offered are the Mary L. Peterson Scholarship and the Esther Materon-Arum Scholarship, named after the two women who helped the Founding Mothers in creating the sorority. ==Membership== {{Main|List of Sigma Lambda Gamma chapters}} A criterion for membership into Sigma Lambda Gamma is that a woman must have exceptional morals and ethics with a demonstrated commitment to academic excellence, and is pursuing or has completed courses leading to a degree in an accredited college or university. Memberships are categorized as undergrad or alumnae. According to Sigma Lambda Gamma's national constitution, they believe that a multicultural experience during the college years enhances each member’s ability to function in a pluralistic society. They do not discriminate on the basis of age, race, national origin, religious preference, sexual orientation or disability. As a result, Sigma Lambda Gamma has a diverse membership that encompasses not only the Latino culture but also the cultural heritages of Native Americans (North, Central and South), Europeans, Africans, Asians and their multiple and interesting mixtures. They encourage their members to celebrate the diverse backgrounds of all the members of the sorority, and currently boasts over 110 nationalities. ===Stance on hazing=== Sigma Lambda Gamma does not condone hazing, and defines it as “any act or tradition that endangers the physical, mental or emotional well-being of an associate and/or initiated member.” Believing that it is their “responsibility to treat all women with the respect and dignity they deserve,” the sorority strive to “maintain a healthy culture that uplifts and supports one another and our community.”{{cite web| title = Anti-Hazing Statement | author = Jimenez, Vanessa | publisher = | date = 2010-10-12|url =http://www.sigmalambdagamma.com/2010/10/12/anti-hazing-statement/ | accessdate = 2014-06-03}}{{cite web| title = Sigma Lambda Gamma taking a stand on Hazing | author = Jimenez, Vanessa | publisher = | date = 2010-10-26|url =https://www.facebook.com/SigmaLambdaGamma/posts/161656787191023 | accessdate = 2014-06-03}} Despite this, several chapters have been shut down for breaching Sigma Lambda Gamma’s anti-hazing policy. The [[University of Florida]] chapter, Rho Alpha, was suspended in 2009 after it was found out that they required their members to run and do push-ups, and they also had rules and restrictions regarding eating, make-up, and how to get to classes.{{cite web| title =Antiquated practice of hazing reveals dark side of Greek life | author =| publisher = Alligator| date = 2009-04-14 |url | accessdate = 2014-06-03}} The University of Nebraska-Lincoln's chapter of Sigma Lambda Gamma, Nu Beta, was placed under one academic year suspension in 2012 for violating the national chapter's '''Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority, Inc. (ΘNΞ)''' is a historically multicultural [[Fraternities and sororities in North America|sorority]] founded on April 11, 1997, at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], by seven women who sought to bridge cultural gaps. Theta Nu Xi was incorporated on April 29, 1999.

In 2001, Theta Nu Xi launched a functional Graduate, Alumnae and Professional (GAP) Program, the first of its kind among multicultural sororities. Theta Nu Xi continues to be the only multicultural sorority with a functional program to initiate and serve professional women beyond the collegiate years.

==History<ref>http://www.thetanuxi.org/history.php</ref>==
Theta Nu Xi was founded during a time when cultural Greek organizations began to proliferate on campuses across the United States. Theta Nu Xi was the first multicultural sorority founded in the [[Southeastern United States]]. The sorority has since grown to over fifty chapters and colonies in its thirteen years of existence.

In the spring of 1996, Melissa Jo Murchison-Blake sought a sisterhood that openly embraced all women and crossed cultural boundaries. As a bi-racial woman, she did not want to choose between historically Caucasian or African-American sororities. Murchison-Blake felt that if she did choose one, she would be denying half of her heritage.

Murchison-Blake recruited six other women who would become the national founders of Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority. In the early days of its existence, the sorority met resistance from its campus of founding.  The Director of Greek Affairs at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill advised the national founders to consider joining an existing organization, expressing his concern that a new Greek organization based on the principle of multiculturalism, would not survive at UNC. Despite such resistance, the national founders' continued efforts set the stage for Theta Nu Xi's presence in the Greek, non-Greek, and surrounding communities.

The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill officially recognized Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority as the Alpha Chapter on April 11, 1997. To commemorate the end result of their perseverance, the national founders - now known as the Founding Monarchs - acknowledged April 11, 1997 as the official founding date of the organization. With the collaborative efforts of the Founding Monarchs and the initiates of Spring 1998, the organization grew exponentially.

The earliest members of Theta Nu Xi addressed an immediate need to develop an official process of expansion which would support new entities as well as serving the interests of the sorority. Under the visionary guidance of Anna Lamadrid, two new chapters of the sorority were founded in the spring of 1999 - one at [[North Carolina State University]] and one at [[University of North Carolina at Greensboro|UNC Greensboro]]. The three groups of women designated themselves Alpha, Beta, and Gamma, respectively, and thus the national organization was born.

The Sorority incorporated on April 29, 1999 and with the participation of the Alpha Chapter and Beta and Gamma Colonies, the National Organization was established at the first annual National Convention on August 21, 1999.  The first out-of-state expansion effort resulted in the founding of a chapter Utah State University in the spring of 2000.

===Graduate, Alumnae, and Professional (GAP) Program<ref>http://www.thetanuxi.org/history.php</ref>===
In the first national constitution, the earliest members of Theta Nu Xi had laid the foundation for an active post-graduate status. On July 19, 2000, 16 women petitioned the National Board to be granted status as an Alumnae Chapter.  These women requested that a structure be put in place that would allow post-collegiate members the ability to participate fully in Sorority activities and the National Organization while a more complete structure was being developed.  The National Board granted the 16 pioneers the equivalent of chapter status, allowing them to send representatives to the 2000 National Convention.

At this Convention, on behalf of the Alumnae Chapter, Soror Jerri Kallam submitted a resolution to establish Alumnae Chapter Standards.  During the same meeting, Soror Amanda Greene, representing the Alpha Chapter, submitted a resolution to create a committee to examine the role of alumnae and professional membership.  These resolutions were adopted and a committee was created.  This committee, composed of Sorors Jerri Kallam, Christie Aden, Shannon Stewart and Melissa Murchison-Blake, was charged with refining and further developing the name, structure and important documents relating to alumnae and professional membership and so sparked the development of an official Graduate, Alumnae and Professional Program.

At the 2001 National Convention, the alumnae committee submitted a GAP policy along with supporting documents.  Through the advocacy of this committee and the success of the program as evidenced by the GAP-initiated women present at Convention, the GAP Program was officially established and became the first of its kind for multicultural sororities.  Founding Monarchs Melissa Murchison-Blake and Janelle Poe, along with Sorors Holly Woodard and Rebecca Treherne, officially chartered the first GAP Chapter on April 11, 2002.

Being the first multicultural sorority to offer an established Graduate, Alumnae and Professional Program, Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority, Inc. began receiving numerous inquiries from interested women.  As more women were initiated at this level, and as undergraduate members graduated, the GAP program became a crucial component of the Sorority's structure.

GAP women now serve on the National Board, support the undergraduate sisterhood as advisors, and participate in all aspects of Sorority operations including expansion teams, national committees, ONEVision - the official Sorority newsletter, and more.

===Values<ref>http://www.thetanuxi.org/values.php</ref>===
The mission of Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority, Inc. is to promote leadership, multiculturalism, and self-improvement through academic excellence, involvement in and service to the [[campus]] and community, as well as being living examples of sisterhood across different races, cultures, religions, backgrounds, and lifestyles.

The tenets of the Sorority are Scholarship, Service, [[Fraternities and sororities|Sisterhood]], [[Leadership]], and [[Multiculturalism]].

The motto of the Sorority is "Sisters of Diversity, Together as ONE".

The objectives of the sorority are to incorporate separate cultures into one life, to build self-esteem through sisterhood, to participate in service activities, especially those concerning diversity in the community, to encourage academic excellence and overall self-improvement,and to promote unity among Greek organizations.

The '''U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce''' was founded in 2001 to increase [[economic growth]] opportunities for women.  As the only national organization of its kind, the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce works in concert with its over 500,000 members, national and local association partners, and key influencers to open doors for women business owners and career professionals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.votesmart.org/issue_group_detail.php?sig_id=319 |title=U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce |accessdate=2009-04-25 |work=Project Vote Smart }}</ref>

==Focus==

Key areas of focus for the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce include:  access to government contracting markets, access to capital for business start-up and growth, access to political office, access to education, and access to career promotions.  In each area, the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce works towards integrating women into the mainstream and providing access to economic advancement.

==History==

In 2005, the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce won a lawsuit against the U.S. Small Business Administration for failure to implement a law passed in 2000 to provide a targeted set-aside program for women-owned businesses seeking federal contracts.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Terry | last=Williams| contribution=Women Business Owners Blocked from Fair Access to Federal Contracts| title=Report to Congress| editor-first=| editor-last=| coeditors=| publisher=U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce| place=Washington, DC| pages=39| date=January 2004| id= | contribution-url=http://www.uswcc.org/report.pdf| format=PDF| accessdate=2009-04-25 }}</ref>  This set-aside was established to help end the disparity in contracting faced by women.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}  Even though women own nearly 30 percent of all businesses in the United States,<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=Survey of Business Owners - Company Summary: 2002 | date=2009-04-03 | publisher=[[U.S. Census]] | url =http://www.census.gov/econ/sbo/02/cosumsof.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-04-25 | language = }}</ref> in 2007 they received only 3.41% of federal contracts.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=Small Business Goaling Report : Fiscal Year 2007 | year=2007 | publisher=[[Small Business Administration]] | url =http://www.sba.gov/idc/groups/public/documents/sba_homepage/fy2007sbgr.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-04-25 | language = }}</ref>

In 2007, the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce filed an amicus brief in support of the women's class action suit against Wal-Mart.<ref name='Dukes v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., No. 04-16688'>{{cite journal|title=US Women’s Chamber of Commerce Amicus Letter|journal=Impact Fund: Strategic Litigation for Social Justice|date=2007-03-27|first=Mark|last=Burton|author2=Jennifer Brown |author3=Gillian Thomas |author4=Jeffrey Bramlett |author5=Michael Terry |author6=Tiana Mykkeltvedt |author7=Margot Dorfman |volume=|issue=|pages=7|id= |url=http://www.impactfund.org/documents/cat_95-100/U.S._Womens_Chamber_of_Commerce,_Amicus_Letter.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2009-04-25 }}</ref>

In 2008, Margot Dorfman, CEO of the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce, provided testimony before the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pension in support of the [[Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009]].<ref>{{Cite book| first=Margot | last=Dorfman| contribution=Testimony of the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce| title=The Fair Pay Restoration Act: Ensuring Reasonable Rules in Pay Discrimination Cases| editor-first=| editor-last=| coeditors=| publisher=Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions| place=Washington, DC| pages=5| date=2008-01-24| id= | contribution-url=http://www.uswcc.org/report.pdf| format=PDF| accessdate=2009-04-25 }}</ref>  Her testimony was cited by Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-VT) as follows, "As the executive director of the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce recently noted, "The Fair Pay Restoration Act rewards those who play fair--including women business owners--unlike the Supreme Court's decision, which seems to give an unfair advantage to those who skirt the rules." This legislation will encourage all corporations to treat their employees fairly."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/record.xpd?id=111-s20090115-19&person=300065 |title=United States Senate, Congressional Record: LILLY LEDBETTER FAIR PAY ACT OF 2009--MOTION TO PROCEED |accessdate=2009-04-25 |date=2009-01-15 |work=GovTrack.us }}</ref>

Leaders and members of the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce are regularly called upon to testify before Congress on small business and economic issues.<ref>{{cite news | first=Margot | last=Dorfman |authorlink= | title=Hearing on Creating Opportunities for Small Businesses in an Economic Recovery | date=2008-10-28 | publisher=[[United States House Committee on Small Business]] | url =http://www.uswcc.org/testimony102808.pdf | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-04-25 | language = }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Margot | last=Dorfman |authorlink= | title=The State of the Small Business Economy and Identifying Policies to Promote an Economic Recovery | date=2009-01-14 | publisher=[[United States House Committee on Small Business]] | url =http://www.house.gov/smbiz/hearings/hearing-01-14-09-stimulus/Dorfman.pdf | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-04-25 | language = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Margot | last=Dorfman |authorlink= | title=The State of SBA’s Entrepreneurial Development Programs and Their Role in Promoting an Economic Recovery | date=2009-02-11 | publisher=[[United States House Committee on Small Business]] | url =http://www.house.gov/smbiz/hearings/hearing-2-11-09-SBA-entrepreneur-development-programs/Dorfman.pdf | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-04-25 | language = }}</ref>

On June 30, 2011, the Small Business Administration accepted the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce as an approved Third Party Certifier for the Women-Owned Small Business Contracting Program.<ref name="SBA Names USWCC as Third Party Certifier for WOSB Program">[http://www.sba.gov/wosb U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce named 3rd Party Certifier for WOSB/EDWOSB Program by U.S. Small Business Administration]</ref>  To further opportunities for women-owned small business federal contractors, the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce established the WOSB National Council.<ref name="WOSB National Council">[http://www.wosbnationalcouncil.org WOSB National Council established by U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce]</ref>

In 2014, the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce established the I Vote for Women.org website<ref name="I Vote for Women">[http://www.ivoteforwomen.org I Vote for Women established by U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce]</ref> to support the election of candidates supporting the chamber's women's economic priorities.<ref name="USWCC | Women's Economic Priorities">[https://www.dropbox.com/s/49sw99hfd9cwlre/USWCC_Womens-Economic-Priorities_July_2014.pdf Women's Economic Priorities as established by U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce]</ref>

On September 11, 2014, the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce filed an amici curiae in support of Peggy Young for her case before the Supreme Court, Young v. UPS No. 12-1226, detailing the economic impact of women in the workforce. <ref name="Amici Curiae">[http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/publications/supreme_court_preview/BriefsV4/12-1226_pet_amcu_uswcoc-etal.authcheckdam.pdf U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce amici curiae Young v. UPS]</ref>

On December 3, 2015, the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce announced their first ever presidential endorsement as they endorsed Secretary Hillary Clinton for the 2016 U.S. Presidential race. The chamber stated that the leadership examined the organization’s priorities along with the history, capability, commitments and electability of current presidential candidates in making the selection. <ref name="U.S. Women’s Chamber of Commerce Endorses Hillary Clinton for President">[https://uswcc.org/2015/12/us-womens-chamber-of-commerce-endorses-hillary-clinton-for-president/ U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce Endorsement of Hillary Clinton 2015-03-12]</ref>

'''UltraViolet''' is a women's advocacy group based in the United States. The group conducts online campaigns using [[social media]] to highlight women's issues such as [[violence against women]], [[maternity leave]], [[equal pay]], and [[reproductive rights]].

==Foundation==
UltraViolet was co-founded in February 2012 by [[Nita Chaudhary]] and [[Shaunna Thomas]]. The name is associated with purple, a color used symbolically in the struggle for [[women's suffrage in the United States]], [[LGBT social movements]], and [[second-wave feminism]]. Co-founder Chaudhary adds that "[[Ultraviolet|UltraViolet lights]] are sort of the most powerful rays on the spectrum and they expose things that people don't want to see, and our mission is to expose things people are uncomfortable confronting, especially with respect to [[sexism]]."<ref name="enews"/>

Within two months of its foundation, UltraViolet had 300,000 members.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bassett|first1=Laura|title=UltraViolet, Women's Rights Group, Upgrades Movement Via Social Media|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/09/ultraviolet-womens-rights_n_1335743.html|work=Huffington Post|date=March 9, 2012}}</ref>

==Campaigns==
UltraViolet has conducted over 30 online campaigns for women's rights. They have also organized protests and phone lobbying.

===Susan G. Komen Foundation===
In February 2012 the [[Susan G. Komen Foundation]] decided to stop funding for breast cancer screenings at [[Planned Parenthood]]. UltraViolet, which had been scheduled to debut in the summer, spearheaded a campaign against Komen with the assistance of MoveOn.org and CREDO SuperPac. They collected nearly one million signatures on a petition that was delivered to the foundation. The foundation reversed its decision and reinstated Planned Parenthood's funding within a week of receiving the petition.<ref name="enews">{{cite news|last1=Hajer|first1=Naili|title=UltraViolet Blazes Trail of Social-Media Triumph|url=http://womensenews.org/story/leadership/130615/ultraviolet-blazes-trail-social-media-triumph#.VBgPUv4ju1E|work=Womens eNews|date=June 17, 2013}}</ref>

Following their victory, UltraViolet campaigned for the resignation of [[Karen Handel]], the Komen Foundation vice president that orchestrated the effort to defund Planned Parenthood. Handel resigned shortly after.<ref name="enews"/>

===Rick Ross===
UltraViolet led a campaign to get [[Reebok]] to end their relationship with rapper [[Rick Ross]] after he rapped about [[date rape|date raping]] a woman in his song "[[U.O.E.N.O.]]".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vega|first1=Tanzina|last2=McKinley, Jr.|first2=James C.|title=Social Media, Pushing Reebok To Drop a Rapper|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/13/arts/music/reebok-drops-rick-ross-after-social-media-protest.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=April 12, 2013}}</ref>

===NFL domestic abuse===
In 2014, following several incidents of domestic abuse by NFL players, UltraViolet called for the resignation of NFL commissioner [[Roger Goodell]]. The group flew aerial banners over three NFL stadiums with the message "#GoodellMustGo".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Strauss|first1=Chris|title=Advocacy group's high-flying message to Roger Goodell hard to miss|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2014/09/15/roger-goodell-ultraviolet-now-advocacy-message/15690171/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+firstcoastnews%2Fsports+%28Firstcoastnews.com+Sports%29|work=USA Today|date=September 16, 2014}}</ref>

===Airport billboards===
In 2014 UltraViolet placed messages on billboards near airports in North Carolina, Texas, Louisiana<ref>{{cite news|last1=Spruill|first1=Constance|title=Ultraviolet Shedding Light on Womens Rights|url=http://guardianlv.com/2014/08/ultraviolet-shedding-light-on-womens-rights/|work=Guardian Liberty Voice|date=August 20, 2014}}</ref> and Ohio. The billboards were critical of state policies towards women.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Borchardt|first1=Jackie|title=Women's pay, women's rights highlighted on Ohio 'tourism' billboards|url=http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2014/08/womens_rights_billboards_go_up.html|work=Plain Dealer|date=August 21, 2014}}</ref>

'''Urgent Action Fund-Africa''' (UAF-Africa) is a [[Pan-African]] [[non-profit organization]] (NPO) focused on women and founded in Nairobi in 2001.  UAF-Africa is the sister organization of the global NPO Urgent Action Fund.<ref name="uaf">[http://www.urgentactionfund-africa.or.ke].</ref>

== Organization ==
UAF-Africa structures itself organizationally into three programs: grant making, collaborative initiatives and communications.

=== Grants ===
UAF-Africa grants rapid response funding up to $5,000 to initiatives across the continent which protect women's human rights.  Several representative grant recipients include: enabling women to take part in national truth and reconciliation processes, relocating women's human rights activists whose lives were in danger because of their activism, sensitizing parliamentarians on an upcoming referendum's ramifications on women's human rights, and empowering women to protect their own rights in conflict situations.<ref name="uaf" />

=== Collaborative initiatives ===
In addition to making grants, UAF-Africa's Collaborative Initiatives Programme aims to strengthen its grantees so they become better able to sustain their activism.  Collaborative Initiatives was created when the organization established that some of goals were best approached by means outside of making grants.<ref name="uaf" />

=== Communication ===
The Communications Program is the newest of the three and helps create a platform for women’s rights issues as well as the organization’s message in order to reach diverse audiences.

== Publications ==
{{Unreferenced section|date=September 2010}}
UAF-Africa has also produced a number literary, academic, and organizational of publications, including:

*Consultative Meeting on [[UN Security Council Resolution 1325]] Kampala, Uganda 
*Gender Focused Rapid Response Teams: A Preliminary Discussion of the Concept and Potential for Implementation London, UK
*Kenya Women Speak on the Proposed Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission 
*Regional Consultation On Engendering Instruments & Mechanisms Of Peacebuilding 
*Solidarity Building: Report of Proceedings of The Consultative Meeting of the Somalia Sudan Kenya Women's Solidarity Forum 
*Rising Up in Response: Women's Rights Activism in Conflict by [[Jane F. Barry]] 
*LGBTI Organizing In East Africa: The True Test for Human Rights Defenders
*ICC Training Manual 
*"This Body!" Supporting Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and Intersex ([[LGBT|LGBTI]]) Organising in East Africa 
*Engendering Transitions: Reflections on Women's Agency in Consolidating Peace in the Great Lakes and Horn of Africa Region 
*Women Defining the Peace and Security Discourse (English & French) 
*Women and Post-Election Nation Building 
*Where is the Money for Women's Rights in Africa (A joint publication with AWDF, [[ActionAid]] International, AWID) 
*Sex Matters

== Founding and leadership ==
UAF-Africa was founded by Betty Kaari Murungi, a lawyer specialising in the areas of women's human rights, gender, and constitutionalism and governance.  In addition to serving as UAF-Africa's director, she has been the legal advisor to the Women's Human Rights Program at [[International Centre for Human Rights and Democratic Development|Rights and Democracy]] in Montreal, Canada.  Ms. Murungi has fought to ensure that the [[International Criminal Court]] and the United Nations [[International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda]] include a gender perspective in their work.  In 2003, Ms. Murungi received The Moran of the Order of the Burning Spear from Kenyan President [[Mwai Kibaki]] for her achievements.<ref name="uaf" />

'''Visayan Forum Foundation, Inc.''' is a non-profit, non-stock and tax-exempt non-government organization in the [[Philippines]] established in 1991. VF works for the welfare of marginalized migrants, especially those working in the invisible and [[informal sector]]s. It works in issues of domestic work, [[child labor]] and [[human trafficking]] especially of women and children.<ref>[http://www.visayanforum.org/aboutus.php Visayan Forum Foundation Inc]</ref>

==Overview==
It is licensed and accredited by the [[Department of Social Welfare and Development]] (DSWD) to provide "residential care and community-based programs and services for women and children in especially difficult circumstances."
It is most known for its pioneering and documented work on [[domestic worker]]s in the Philippines, especially in pushing for the Domestic Workers Bill or the Batas Kasambahay. It is also in the forefront of providing services to trafficking victims by managing Halfway Houses constructed by the [[Philippine Ports Authority]] and the [[Manila International Airport Authority]] in major Philippine ports.

VF's work for child domestic workers has been cited by ILO-IPEC and the [[United Nations]] Girls Education Initiative (UNGEI) as one of the international best practices. Its anti-trafficking partnership with the Philippine government and private shipping companies was also hailed as one of the international best practices by the U.S. State Department in its 2005 Trafficking in Persons (TIP) Report. The Anti-Slavery International, the world's oldest human rights organization, also conferred the 2005 Anti-Slavery award on VF's President.

In September 2012, questions were raised about possible fraud by the organization. The investigation is ongoing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/12363-usaid-sues-ph-s-top-trafficking-fighter|title=USAID sues PH's top trafficking fighter|work=Rappler|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>

==History==
The Visayan Forum Foundation Inc. (VFF), a nonprofit organization was founded in 1991.
Based in Quezon City, the Visayan Forum Foundation has rescued and helped more than 32,000 victims and potential victims of trafficking.<ref name="america.gov">http://www.america.gov/st/hr-english/2009/January/20090128141723ajesrom0.1934473.html&distid=ucs</ref>

These days the Visayan Forum now has its own national office in Manila — plus a network of over 70 staff workers, six regional offices, and seven project areas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pcij.org/stories/ma-cecilia-flores-oebanda/|title=Ma. Cecilia Flores-Oebanda|publisher=|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>

==National and international efforts in mobilizing social partners==
* Philippine and Southeast Asian Secretariat, Global March against Child Labor
* Convenor, Task Force on Child Domestic Workers in Asia
* Convenor, Multi-Sectoral Network against Trafficking in Persons (MSNAT)
* Convenor, Anti-Trafficking Task Forces at the Ports
* Vice-Chair, Philippine NGO Coalition on the UNCRC
* Member, ILO Convention 182 National Monitoring Team
* Member, National Steering Committee of UNICEF’s Sixth Country Program for Children

==Vision==
A society where marginalized migrants, especially Filipino women and children, are free and empowered.

==Mission==
To contribute to the protection, freedom and empowerment of marginalized migrants, especially Filipino women and children, by:

# Mobilizing local, national and international efforts that promote safe migration and work for the development of marginalized migrants, especially the invisible domestic workers and trafficked women and children.
# Providing integrative services and interventions
# Campaigning, capacity-building and organizing advocates and volunteers as agents of change towards policies and programs that sustain long-term development involving women and children, communities, and other social partners.
# Leading and sustaining preventive and proactive community-based programs

==Goals==
Institutionalized local, national and international policies that shall protect and provide programs and services for women and children especially the mainstreaming of domestic workers and trafficked persons.
Sustained networks, partners, support or survivor groups and other stakeholders to provide protection, justice and developmental opportunities for long-term implementation of programs and services to victims of trafficking, abusive domestic work, as well as other vulnerable groups.
Interventions for victims of trafficking and abusive domestic work are set up and strengthened in strategic areas, ports and hotspots.
Communities are economically viable and secured.

==Projects==
*A halfway house, dubbed "Balay Silungan sa Daungan" (Home Shelter at the Port) provides 24-hour "safety and catchment" services for victims of trafficking intercepted by child rights advocates and government personnel.
The center, jointly established by the Visayan Forum Foundation (VF) and the PPA, also provides victims of child trafficking a temporary shelter, referrals in pursuing legal actions against their recruiters and telephone hotline counseling. VF-Mindanao regional coordinator, Luzviminda Panes, said the center also provides mechanisms to protect children who travel alone or are stranded at the seaport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cpcabrisbane.org/Kasama/2002/V16n2/VisayanFF.htm|title=Center for Victims of Child Trafficking Inaugurated|publisher=|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>

==Human trafficking==
Visayan Forum Foundation has been actively involved in helping women and children trafficked into prostitution by providing support, education, housing, and legal advice.
Visayan Forum Foundation has established that most of the children and young women trafficked to Manila from rural areas in search of work are assured jobs as domestic workers, but in a significant number of cases end up in the sex trade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antislavery.org/archive/submission/submission2002-childlabour.htm|title=Anti-Slavery|author=dotMailer|publisher=|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref> Based on the statistics provided by the Visayan Forum Foundation, most victims are between 12 and 22 years old.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://technology.inquirer.net/infotech/infotech/view/20060603-3606/IT_skills_training_enlisted_in_fight_vs_human_trafficking|title=IT skills training enlisted in fight vs human trafficking - INQUIRER.net, Philippine News for Filipinos|publisher=|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>

The Visayan Forum work with the Philippine coast guard, the government's Port Authority, and shipping company, Aboitez, to keep monitor arriving boats in the main ports, looking for possible traffickers traveling with groups of children.
The organization has operations in four main ports serving Manila, and says it rescues between 20 and 60 children a week.<ref name="voanews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/a-13-Child-Trafficking-Prevalent-Throughout-Southeast-Asia-67390462.html|title=Child Trafficking Prevalent Throughout Southeast Asia|work=VOA|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>

===Regional centers===
[[Metro Manila]], [[Batangas]], [[Bacolod]], [[Davao City|Davao]], [[Sorsogon]].

===Other project areas===
NCR, Batangas, Sorsogon, Cebu, Iloilo, Negros Occidental, Negros Oriental, Davao, Southern Leyte, Samar, Surigao, and Zamboanga.

==Awards==
Maria Cecilia Flores-Oebanda of the Visayan Forum Foundation is the first person to win the Iqbal Masih Award for the Elimination of Child Labor, a new honor bestowed by the U.S. Department of Labor.
Maria Cecilia Flores-Oebanda was presented with the award by Kristie Kenny, the U.S. ambassador to the Philippines.<ref name="america.gov"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visayanforum.org/portal/index.php?option=cms&mode=view&id=867|title=Visayan Forum -|publisher=|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>

In 2005, Maria Cecilia Flores-Oebanda of the Visayan Forum Foundation received the Anti-Slavery Award from Anti-Slavery International, the world’s oldest human rights organization.<ref name="america.gov"/>

In 2009, the Visayan Forum Foundation was awarded the Eduardo Aboitiz Award for Outstanding Institution.<ref>http://67.225.139.201/cebu/doctor-visayan-forum-win-prestigious-awards-0</ref>

==Harassment==
Ms. Ulleque says those arrested for trafficking children will sometimes threaten workers from her organization.
"Sometimes they send their lawyers here and also they say, 'I am the relative of senator so-and-so and I am the friend of the station commander or the port police,' something like that, so we are being harassed".<ref name="voanews.com"/>

==Fraud allegation==

An accusation of fraud by the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) was filed before the Department of Justice (DOJ) on behalf of USAID. In the fall of 2012, the Visayan Forum Foundation's office in Manila was raided by the NBI, and evidence collected includes 35 boxes of allegedly fake documents, with around 10 folders per box and around 100 documents per folder. USAID complained against VF over P210-M (US$5.1-M) in donations that the non-government organization (NGO) allegedly misused out of a P300-M (US$7.3-M) port project. The project was meant to shelter human trafficking victims in airports and harbors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/15852-visayan-forum-from-us-hero-to-foe|title=Visayan Forum: From U.S. 'hero' to foe|work=Rappler|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>

In July 2016, the Supreme Court of Philippines affirmed the validity of a search warrant issued by a Quezon City court in 2012 and 2013 against Visayan over unexplained disbursements of over P200 million (USD$5.1m) from USAID in the ongoing fraud case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/574730/news/nation/sc-backs-search-warrant-vs-visayan-forum-over-p200-m-usaid-fund-mess|title = SC backs search warrant vs. Visayan Forum over P200-M USAID fund mess |work=GMA|accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bworldonline.com/content.php?section=Nation&title=sc-sustains-search-warrant-on-usaid-financed-visayan-forum&id=130833| title =SC sustains search warrant on USAID-financed Visayan Forum|work=Business World|accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref>

According to CNN, Visayan operations have slumped to almost zero after allegations of fraud were made by USAID in September 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/05/06/world/asia/freedom-fighters-record/index.html|title =Visayan Forum anti-trafficking operations|work=CNN|accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref>

'''Vital Voices Global Partnership''' is an American international, [[non-profit]], [[non-governmental organization]] that works with women leaders in the areas of economic empowerment, women's political participation, and human rights. The organization is headquartered in [[Washington, D.C.]].

==History==

The nonprofit Vital Voices Global Partnership grew out of the U.S. government's Vital Voices Democracy Initiative. The Vital Voices Democracy Initiative was established in 1997 by [[First Lady of the United States]] [[Hillary Clinton]] and [[U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Madeleine Albright]], following the [[United Nations]] [[Fourth World Conference on Women]] in [[Beijing]] to promote the advancement of women as a [[U.S. foreign policy]] goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vitalvoices.org/about-us/our-history |title=History of Vital Voices |publisher=Vital Voices |accessdate=2010-03-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20100124120629/http://vitalvoices.org:80/about-us/our-history |archivedate=January 24, 2010 }}</ref> The first Vital Voices Democracy Initiative conference was held in 1997 in Vienna, and hosted by U.S. Ambassador to Austria [[Swanee Hunt]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/WPcap/2000-02/16/028r-021600-idx.html | title=First Lady Listens to Vital Voices | publisher=Washington Post | accessdate=2013-01-15 | date=2000-02-16}}</ref>

The Vital Voices Democracy Initiative led to the creation of Vital Voices Global Partnership as a nonprofit non-governmental organization (NGO) in March 1999.

Former Hillary Clinton aide and chief of staff [[Melanne Verveer]] is co-founder of the global partnership and its board chair emeritus.<ref name="vvdir">{{cite web | url=http://www.vitalvoices.org/desktopdefault.aspx?page_id=9 | title=Vital Voices - Board of Directors | publisher=Vital Voices | accessdate=2007-10-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070904132611/http://www.vitalvoices.org/desktopdefault.aspx?page_id=9 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-04}}</ref> Other co-founders were Alyse Nelson (current President of Vital Voices Global Partnership),<ref>{{cite web | url=http://washingtonscene.thehill.com/people/3125-alyse-nelson | title=Alyse Nelson profile | publisher=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | year=2011 | accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref> Donna McLarty, Mary Yerrick, and Theresa Loar.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GcPc5Ef57OIC&pg=PA220 | title= America's Commitment Women 2000 | publisher=[[The White House]] | date=2000-01-05 | accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>  Loar was the founding President of the Vital Voices Global Partnership<ref>{{cite news | url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50D1FF6345E0C758CDDAF0894DA404482 | title=Powell Report on Slave Trading | publisher=The New York Times | date=2002-06-06 | accessdate=2011-01-30 | first=Todd S. | last=Purdum}}</ref>  and also served as Director of the Vital Voices Democracy Initiative at the U.S. Department of State, the Senior Coordinator for International Women's' Issues at the U.S. Department of State<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.princeton.edu/main/news/archive/S04/28/19O80/index.xml | title= Global Partnership for Women | publisher=[[Princeton University]] | date=2003-10-17 | accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref> and Director of the President's Interagency Council on Women.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.carnegieendowment.org/events/index.cfm?fa=eventDetail&id=94& | title= Trafficking in Women: International Cooperation | publisher=[[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace]] | date=1997-09-29 | accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>

Besides Clinton, honorary chairs include current and former U.S. Senators [[Kay Bailey Hutchison]] and [[Nancy Kassebaum Baker]].<ref name="vvdir"/>

Funding has come from a variety of sources, including individual donations; corporate sponsors such as [[ExxonMobil]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.exxonmobil.com/Corporate/news_speeches_20070118_RAL.aspx | title=vital voices of Africa: pan-African summit for women and girls | author=Roberta Luxbacher | publisher=[[ExxonMobil]] | date=2007-01-18 | accessdate=2007-10-25}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> [[Standard Chartered Bank]], and [[Bank of America]]; foundations such as the Avon Foundation for Women and Humanity United;<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.vitalvoices.org/About%20Us/Financials | title=Financials | publisher=Vital Voices | accessdate=2013-01-15}}</ref> and the efforts of the [[Clinton Global Initiative]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://archive.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2006/3/31/91014.shtml | title=Bill Clinton Hoping for Billions in Pledges for His Charity | publisher=[[NewsMax]] | date=2006-03-31 | accessdate=2007-10-25}}</ref>

In 2002 Vital Voices was asked by First Lady [[Laura Bush]] to drive the effort to supply school uniforms to the many girls returning to school for the first time following the  [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|U.S. led overthrow]] of the [[Taliban]] in [[Afghanistan]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A02E3DF173AF932A05750C0A9649C8B63 | title= 'A' for Afghan, 'S' for Schoolgirl | author=Kari Haskell | publisher=The New York Times | date=2002-03-31 | accessdate=2007-10-25}}</ref>

==Mission and programs==

Vital Voices' website states that its mission is "to identify, invest in and bring visibility to extraordinary women around the world by unleashing their leadership potential to transform lives and accelerate peace and prosperity in their communities."<ref>[http://vitalvoices.org/about-us/ ]{{dead link|date=July 2016}}</ref>

Vital Voices works in [[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Eurasia]], [[Latin America]] and the Caribbean and the [[Middle East]] and [[North Africa]], focusing on the business, political and civil society sectors. The organization regularly hosts international forums, capacity-building workshops, and training seminars for women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vitalvoices.org/what-we-do/ |title=What We Do |publisher=Vital Voices |date=2016-06-20 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref>

Vital Voices’ Human Rights program currently focuses on combating [[human trafficking]] and other forms of [[violence against women]] and girls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vitalvoices.org/what-we-do/issues/human-rights |title=Human Rights |publisher=Vital Voices |date=2016-06-20 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref>

==Global Leadership Awards==

Vital Voices hosts the annual [[Global Leadership Awards]], honoring women leaders working in the areas of human rights, economic empowerment, or political reform. The 2009 ceremony was described as that year's "Most Inspirational Event" in Washington, D.C. in an article in Washington Life Magazine.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonlife.com/2009/12/10/washington-social-diary-we-pick-2009-best-events/ | title=The 2010 Social List: Year in Review | publisher=Washington Life | accessdate=2010-03-06}}</ref>

'''Voices of Men''' is a movement in the Fox Valley area of Northeast [[Wisconsin]] to end [[domestic violence]] against women. The group was formed by area men to take a stand against the abuse and violence on women. January 12, 2010 the group held campaign a kickoff event that had over 400 local men in attendance.<ref name="Website">[http://www.voicesofmen.com/PDFs/011210.pdf Post-Crescent Article]</ref> The message is spread through simulations, workplace educational opportunities, coaching seminars, video discussions, area events and many other ways.

Voices of Men works as a partner to four Fox Valley agencies: Christine Anne Domestic Abuse Services, Harbor House Domestic Abuse Programs, Reach Counseling Services and the Sexual Assault Crisis Center. The four agencies joined efforts to effectively communicate the truth about men's violence against women. Ben Atherton-Zeman created the comical one-man performance which was the inspiration for the group. He performed locally for over 600 students and about 130 other people in the community. After much success of his performances and a fall event called "Men's Summit," Fox Valley Voices of Men was formed to keep the effort of ending violence against women going."<ref name="Article">[http://www.voicesofmen.com/ Voices of Men Website]</ref>

The mission statement of the group is "Voices of Men is a group of Fox Valley men dedicated to ending violence in our community and preventing the abuse of girls and women through education, role modeling and mentoring of boys and men."<ref name="Article"/> The philosophy of this group is about preventing violence and abuse by being part of the solution, not the problem. It aims at getting at the root cause by educating people on violence against women.<ref name="Interview">[http://www.voicesofmen.com/PDFs/012910.pdf Post-Crescent: Interview with Beth Schnorr]</ref>
